story: NewsLonely Britain as one in ten people go more than a week without human contactSurvey shows one in five people will be lonely this holiday seasonShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  DEC NewsFeeling alone can affect all age groups "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMore than one in  people are lonely and often go more than a week without any human contact. A poll for the Mirror finds loneliness is widespread across all generations, with young people just as likely to feel isolated as the elderly. The ComRes survey shows one in five people will be lonely this holiday season and one in  will spend Christmas alone.And more than one in  go more than a week without seeing or speakshyshying to a friend, shyrelative or neighbour.The poll underlines how young people find it harder to make friends and get to know their neighbours than the older generation. Just over one in  of  to -year-olds are in daily contact with their neighbours compared with nearly three in  of those aged  and over. Seven in  young adults report feeling lonely, compared with one-third of the older generation. They are also more likely to go without company for longer periods. More than half of young peoplesay they find it dficult to make friends.   People surveyed admitted they have caught a bus, gone to a coffee shop or gone shopping for human contact. Loneliness is particularly high in London, with % of adults admitting to feeling lonely. The “least lonely” regions are Wales and the East Midlands, both on %. Laura Alcock-Ferguson, executive director of the Campaign to End shyLoneliness, said: “We know it can affect people at any age. It is very positive to see younger people are able to be open about their experiences. The stigma is deeply isolating and we hope younger people can help drive a change in culture that will eradicate that stigma. “We know older people tend to feel the stigma more. Our  research into attitudes to loneliness found more than half of adults say admitting to shyloneliness is dficult. “More than three-quarters of over-s would find it hard to admit to feeling lonely because they do not want to be a burden. “We need to remain vigilant to ensure older people aren’t overlooked. This is a swtly growing shydemographic. The number of lonely over-s is set to hit two million within seven years. “Older people are still far more likely to experience chronic loneliness, with devastating health impacts.”ComRes surveyed , adults online between November  and .

title: number kids temporary accommodation up
story: NewsNumber of kids in temporary accommodation up % since Tories came to powerLabour have blamed Conservative policies for the riseShareByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsThe numbers have shot up since  "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory policies blamed for severe rise in the number of kids in temporary accommodation. The figure has shot up by % since they came to power in . Labour’s Shadow Housing Secretary John Healey said decisions to slash investment for affordable homes, cut back housing benefit, reduce funding for homelessness services, and deny protection to private renters had all contributed. The latest figures also reveal that in London nearly , children are without a permanent home to call their own. The figure is , in East of England, , in the East Midlands, , in the South East, , in the South West, , in the West Midlands and , in the North. Figures buried in the website of the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government show that in the second quarter of  , children were living in temporary accommodation up % from , in Q of .   The figures refer to the number of children in temporary accommodation accepted by local authorities. Homeless charity Shelter believes that there are , homeless people living in temporary accommodation in the UK. John Healey told the Mirror: “When this Conservative Government ends, the national shame of rising homelessness will be on its political tombstone. “Homelessness fell at an unprecedented rate under Labour, but under the Tories even more children will be homeless this Christmas. He added: “The next Labour Government will end rough sleeping within a Parliament and tackle the root causes of rising homelessness with more affordable homes and stronger rights for renters.” Figures collected for the first time and released last week showed deaths of homeless people are up a quarter in the past five years. The figures were thrown into relief when it emerged that a rough sleeper had died outside the underground entrance to Parliament.  Gyula Remes was found collapsed in the tunnel linking parliament to Westminster station - he later died in hospital. Rough sleeping is up % since , including a % rise between  and . The Government has said that there are , sleeping rough in the UK. Initially Housing Seretary James Brokenshire blamed the rise on drugs, mental health and family breakdown. But earlier this week he admitted government policy may have played a role, saying: “We do have to look and reflect on ourselves as to the increase.” Commenting on the rise of children in temporary accommodation, Minister for Homelessness Heather Wheeler MP said: “No family should be left without a roof over their head, and we are working to ensure all children have a safe place to stay. “Councils have a duty to provide temporary accommodation for families with nowhere to go, and we have been clear that they also have a duty to prevent homelessness in the first place.” “We’re providing more than pound.bn to tackle all forms of homelessness, including amongst children, and introduced the Homelessness Reduction Act to ensure people at risk get help quicker. “With the changes Government has made I am looking forward to more councils building new homes, helping families have a safe, affordable place to live.”

title: children sleep bristol airport baggage
story: NewsChildren sleep on Bristol Airport baggage carousel after being locked in overnightPassengers at Bristol Airport were frustrated after being stuck in the baggage reclaim all for hours in the middle of the nightShareCommentsByTristan CorkKelly-Ann Mills:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsFrustrated passengers and tired children wait on baggage carousel "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFrustrated passengers have slammed Bristol Airport after they were left waiting for hours in the middle of the night for their bags. People arriving at the airport on Sunday evening were delayed taking off for their flights to Bristol. But after arriving later than planned they they faced a wait of more than three hours to get their bags from the planes. The baggage reclaim area was reportedly full of ‘tired and grumpy’ passengers, with children sleeping on the baggage carousel. Passengers claimed they were ‘locked in’ the reclaim hall for hours, Bristol Live reports. Airport bosses said there were a number of ‘off-schedule flights’ arriving at the time, which caused a backlog in baggage handling. A spokesman promised a review into what went wrong. But frustrated passengers lambasted the airport and the baggage handling set-up on Twitter, with one even claiming it was quicker to sort out the Brexit deal than get the baggage off the planes. Twitter user Steve first began to complain after waiting for an hour and a half for his bags to emerge from a flight into Bristol from Berlin. “Whats going on  ” he asked Bristol Airport. “Meeting Berlin flight waiting for mins for luggage!! Unacceptable.”  Then, while the wait continued and more passengers arrived, he said: “An hour and three quarters now. This is the bread and butter of your job and you clearly arent capable of doing it. Its not like a load of unexpected planes can turn up! “Two hours now - you realize Santa will be unloading gt billion presents tomorrow night. Might be worth askinghe does training,” he joked. Finally, the bags from the Berlin flight began to arrive on the carousel. “Two hours  mins in the end - Mrs May makes faster progress on Brexit than that!” he said. Darren Sainty said his flight in from Paris had been delayed by four hours in France, and then the bags took three hours to be unloaded off the plane. He described ‘children sleepingbaggage belts’. And Rachel Baker complained her simple one-hour flight from Glasgow to Bristol turned into a nightmare. “Thanks for such a fun night,” she said. “Look at all these happy faces, at Glasgow airport at pm for a one-hour flight, past am and still waiting for our luggage in Bristol. Locked in a room with no information and nowhere to sit, she added. The delays were also felt by friends and family waiting on the other side of the passport control in the arrivals hall. Pat Seymour was one, who waited for hours for her son to emerge from the Berlin flight. He arrived on an easyJet flight from Berlin, he landed at midnight and came through baggage reclaim at .am, she said. I was the other side waiting for one of the tired, grumpy people. I can certainly testy to weary passengers and exhausted children coming through from baggage reclaim when they eventually got their luggage.  The only people available to speak to were security staff and the young lady on the information desk. One lady who was waiting asked herit would be possible to speak to the Swissport duty manager and was informed that they were probably in the baggage hall. I don’t knowshe did manage to get anyone to come and speak to her, but my son said there was no one there to speak to about the situation when I asked him, she added. Pierluigi Stanzione was waiting for his -year-old mum to arrive for Christmas from Naples. She was due to arrive at Bristol Airport at .pm on Sunday evening, but didnt actually take off from the southern Italiian city until .pm. She didnt get off the plane until midnight, but her baggage didnt arrive in the baggage hall until .am. No one said a word until my mum complained and only at that point passengers were told that the flight was delayed so there was no staff from Swissport to unload the luggage, he said. A spokesperson for Bristol Airport apologised to passengers. “Sorry for the delay that you experienced,” passengers were told. “This was caused by a number of off schedule flights arriving at the time. Airport staff were in location to assist with information and queries. On behalf of your airline we apologise for the delay,” she added. A spokesperson told Bristol Live: Delays were experienced to the arrival of passengers baggage overnight Sunday, December  and Monday, December  to a small number of flights. This was caused due to flight disruption across the flight schedule earlier in the day. As a result of the knock-on effect with the delayed flights arriving off scheduled, airline ground handling resources were stretched at times, meaning some passengers experienced baggage delays. We continue to work with our airline handling partners to limit the inconvenience caused to passengers. Airline handling and customer service staff were present in the baggage reclaim area assisting during the delay. Bristol Airport apologises and appreciates the frustration passengers experienced due to the delay in the arrival of their bags. An internal investigation with the airline handling agent will be completed, she added. The baggage handling at Bristol Airport is done by a company called Swissport. “We are aware that there were a signicant number of flights arriving off schedule at Bristol airport on the evening of the rd and early on the th, causing a knock-on impact to baggage reclaim for passengers, said a Swissport spokesperson. “We work closely with our airline and airport partners to mitigate the impact of these schedule disruptions to passengers and we understand these delays were frustrating to passengers during this busy holiday period, he added.

title: how to make roast potatoes
story: NewsHow to make the best roast potatoes - top tips to guarantee crispinessHeston Blumenthal has a few tips for how to make the perfect roast potatoesShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience WriterJoshua Barrie:,  DEC NewsSave on spuds: Roast potatoes and sprouts are both down in price from last year "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMost of us reckon we can absolutely nail roast potatoes, but although we have our tried and tested methods sometimes theyre just not as good as they were last time. Every now and again, what you hoped would be a perfect tray of roasties , has been a little disappointing. And with Christmas just around the corner, the last thing you want is less-than-perfect potatoes on the day - especiallyyouve got family to impress. Luckily for you, none other than Heston Blumenthal has some top tips on how to get it right - and we reckon he knows his stuff on this one. Heres three essential tips for roasting your potatoes to perfection, and theyre so simple that theres really no excuse for getting it wrong next time.  Number one, make sure you parboil those badboys. Most cooks know to boil before roasting. Season the pan, leave the spuds to cook, then throw them in a baking tray with oil or fat, salt, pepper, maybe a sprig of rosemary and a couple of garlic cloves. But theres a major issue when it comes to timing, according to three Michelin-starred chef Heston Blumenthal. Heston advises leaving potatoes in to boil for  minutes before roasting - which is longer than most of us do as it almost cooks them through. He also suggests putting the peelings in the cooking water to improve the flavour. Good idea.  Number two, you need to scuff up those potatoes as you drain them to make sure they go extra crispy. You could do this by giving them a bit of a shake in the colander, but dont do it too hard. Basically, you want them to crumble just a little, so that the oil or fat covers a wider surface area and penetrates deeper into the potato. If you really want that crispiness, this genius tip is guaranteed to get results - and it may seem a little unusual. What you need to do is score the potatoes with a fork. This creates ridges and grooves, perfect for golden, crispy goodness. Thirdly, Heston also says that metal baking trays are best. Avoid glass or Pyrex. Metal is a better conductor, so the oil will get hotter faster, which means a crispier exterior. Have you got a hot tip for perfect roast potatoes  Let us know in the comments!

title: its been difficult year love
story: NewsopinionIts been a dficult year, but love and goodwill will get us throughYasmin Alibhai-Brown says when everything is falling apart, we must keep faith in humanityShareByYasmin Alibhai-Brown:,  DEC NewsopinionThe shrine at Westminster tube station to homeless man Gyula Remes "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhat a draining, depressing year it’s been. One -year-old man in a care home wrote in a letter to a newspaper: “What has happened  What have we become ”Many of us are asking these same questions. Remember the way we were in , during the Olympics   How did Britain become so ided, so unequal, selfish and intolerant  Pessimism is understandable, but it is a dark hole we can’t climb out of.When everything is falling apart, we must keep faith in humanity. Millions of our citizens are stepping up, doing their bit to make le better for others. Look and you will see extraordinary generosity and connections between the ious people of this rainbow nation.Take two pressing issues. In the week before Christmas , a homeless man, Gyula Remes, only , died just outside Parliament. Over the last five years there has been a % increase in such tragic deaths. We know that because, finally, we are counting bodies and naming them. Most are men, most too young.There is now real public concern about these lives and deaths. This year, homeless shycharities have been turning away Christmas volunteers as so many have come forward. Yes, shyamazingly, there is an oversupply of people who wanted to turn up and help. My son – usually fairly greedy for stuff – didn’t want any presents and he asked us to buy places for rough sleepers to go to Crisis. story: NewsMum spends a thousand pounds to put on a Christmas dinner for lonely peopleMum-of-two Mo Fayose and a group of  volunteers cooked up a feast at a sheltered housing complex in NottinghamShareByMark CardwellLouie Smith:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC News "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA selfless mum organised a Christmas dinner for more than  isolated and lonely people. Mo Fayose, , and a group of  volunteers have cooked up a feast at a sheltered housing complex today. They served turkey, chicken, fish, caullower soup, butternut squash and swede soup, salmon canapeacutes, garlic and herb canapeacutes - and of course Brussels sprouts. Mo, who has been holding similar events for several years, spent over pound of her own money paying for the food. The mum-of-two said: “This is for people who are isolated - who can’t get out of the house, elderly people, people with children. “The oldest person who has attended has been . “When people start seeing Christmas stuff on the shelves and the lights go up, it sends people into depression.   “Butthey know there is a group of them in the community, it makes them happy. “I use a mobile cooker in the garden of the building with a marquee. “I have volunteers, and we decorate it aswe are having a wedding. Mo planned to host her first public Christmas meal at her Nottingham home several years ago. But the idea “went viral” forcing her to find a bigger venue and enlist the help of volunteers. This years event cost more than pound, to put on, with  per cent of the funds provided by Mo and the rest coming from charitable donations. As well as hosting the care home meal the team also delivered Christmas dinners to those in the community.  Charity worker Mo added: “I got the idea for it when I was doing my mental health nursing degree. “I was so excited because it was Christmas - but one patient said to me ‘stop it, woman - not everybody likes Christmas’. “She said she wasn’t looking forward to Christmas because it’s a lonely time. “I then did research into festive loneliness, and found out many people would rather be in hospital than at home, because they wouldn’t be on their own on Christmas day. “I now do this throughout the year for elderly people and people in independent living.   “I am orced, and I was lonely as well - I didn’t realise until I started doing this. “I find it fascinating to come together with people who all share similar journeys with me. This year, Mo fell into hot water when Nottingham City Council ordered her to take down flyers she had posted around the city advertising the event. But the council, which had previously praised her work, later backed down and allowed her to continue posting her material. Councillor Linda Woodings, representing the Basford ward of Nottingham, said it was a really worthy cause and there had been a genuine misunderstanding.

title: mum woke up christmas morning
story: NewsMum woke up on Christmas morning to find her hair had fallen outJanine Vickery, , from Birmingham, cried in the shower after discovering her locks strewn across her pillow before facing the day ahead - here she tells her story about how she survived stage  breast cancer.ShareCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills:,  DEC News "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum woke up on Christmas morning to find her hair had fallen out - after dreading the moment would come. Janine Vickery, , from Birmingham, cried in the shower after discovering her locks strewn across her pillow before facing the day - she told her story about how she survived Stage  breast cancer to Birmingham Live. This is her story, in her words: On November  , my le changed in a split second. I was diagnosed with grade  invasive aggressive breast cancer which had spread to my lymph nodes. I had lost a grandparent to cancer. This may sound very naive, but to me cancer was usually what older people get, not young women, especially not breast cancer. I was not aware that there was history of it in our family until I was diagnosed. I suppose it’s just something that isn’t really spoken about but really it should be.  My nanna’s sister died from breast cancer years back. MaybeI had known I would have been more cautious, who knows  Before I was diagnosed my le was pretty hectic. I am a single mother to my -year-old daughter Abigail. I was studying an access course to hopefully continue on to university to become a nurse. I was very active at the gym and had a busy social le. During the weeks before I found out I was feeling fit and well, in fact the best I had felt in a long time. I needed some asthma inhalers so I booked an appointment with my GP. I mentioned the cysts in my breasts and askedI could get them removed. He said I seemed very anxious and asked why I was worrying but saidit made me feel better he would book an appointment at a breast clinic. So a week later I attended the clinic and after waiting two-and-half hours I was seen and had a scan and a mammogram. A doctor said it was cysts and nothing to worry about and I was told I could go. Later I received a phone call to say they hadn’t finished what they had to do and they should never have discharged me and asked me to go back a week later.  When I ed I was told they were to do a biopsy on my left breast. They did the needle biopsy on me which was an extremely horrying and painful procedure. The doctor told me he was  per cent sure that it was nothing and not to worry. So a week later I go to my appointment for my results. To be told you have a tumour that is breast cancer was devastating, my world fell apart. I was utterly terried. The first thing I said was “Am I going to die ” The doctor replied “We all die Janine.” I was shocked at his response. It felt like it wasn’t happening. I just cried and started shaking, from that moment on everything was a blur. Everything that was said I can’t remember – I went into completely shock. It’s something you never think will ever happen to you. The hardest part was telling my love ones, especially my daughter, it broke my heart.  The thought of not seeing my daughter getting married or see her grow up into the wonderful lady I know she is becoming was tearing me up inside but I had to try my hardest to not think about it and put it to the back of my head. I had two weeks to wait until I had the results from my MRI to tell methe cancer had spread into my body. It was the worst two weeks of my le – I even started planning my funeral and what I would doI was told I only had so long to live. During the period leading up to finding out my results my back was so painful, so painful I could hardly walk so I was convinced the cancer had spread. Even though I’m usually a very positive person – I just couldn’t help it. When the news came that it hadn’t spread I cried with relief. It’s amazing how much stress can effect your body. My body was in complete shock from being told and waiting for results because after that my back was better. I started my chemotherapy four weeks later. It was a very daunting time and my anxiety was terrible worrying about how I would be able to cope looking after my daughter and how ill I was going to be. I couldn’t sleep too – there were many thoughts and emotions going round and round my head. Somehow I found the strength to get through thanks to my amazing family and friends. My hair fell out within two weeks of having treatment which was very hard to take, even worse as it started to fall out on Christmas Day.  As it fell out it was very painful, more fell out each day until I was left with strands so decided to cut it off. I have got used to wearing my wigs now but I still can’t wait for the day my hair starts growing back. Luckily I have the most amazing wig made by the lovely Natalie Perez – it’s felt amazing and shocked everyone with how natural it looks. As my immune system was low whilst on treatment I kept catching infections, I caught CDan infection in the stomach. I don’t think I ever felt so bad in my le – I really thought I was dying. Slowly I started improving and after two weeks I was allowed to go home. I had a scan and unfortunately my tumour had grown from cm to cm in a few months. The chemotherapy wasn’t shrinking the tumour. They decided to stop my chemo and operate straight away and remove my left breast because the cancer had spread into my milk ducts. The whole breast had to be removed including  lymph nodes, of which half were infected. The day came when I had to have the operation. Strangely I wasn’t scared. In my head I just wanted the tumour gone. The doctors and surgeons at Burton Hospital were all amazing and put me at ease. My surgeon was the most compassionate, caring, lovely woman I have ever met. She made sure my scar wasn’t straight across my breast, but did it round so when I have my new boobs hopefully the scar will be underneath. When I woke up apparently I was laughing about having one boob, I made them all laugh and they said after a five-hour operation that was a first.  The first time I saw my naked body it really didn’t faze me at all, I thought I might cry but I didn’t. I just felt relieved that horrible tumour was out of my body. After two months I was back on a dferent chemotherapy, every week through a line that was in my arm. Everything was going well until I went and caught another bad infection where I was rushed in an ambulance to Burton Hospital as my temperature was very high. I was put straight back on antibiotics through a drip to kill the infection. Again I started improving and was allowed home. I had nine weeks of chemo through my line, and couldn’t wait to finish as it made me so weak. I finally got there and finished my chemo. I had to dig very deep at times and keep mentally strong and I really believe that is half the battle, I am very lucky as I have amazing friends and family who picked me up when they could see I was getting low. I still can’t believe I’m here and come out the other end and hopefully I’m going to be okay. The last ten months have been horric. The feelings, thoughts and pain I have felt no one should ever go through. But I want to get something positive out of this and try to help people who are going through this awful journey feel better about themselves. Even though you have cancer you can still get your eyebrows tattooed before you start chemotherapy. That’s what I did and I’m so glad, eyebrows make such a dference to the face. I have my lips and eyebrows tattooed, I have inidual lashes that I now get done every three weeks. If you do have to suffer this awful journey then why not hold your head up high and still be the old you and stay glamorous. Do not let it win! My le is finally going in the direction I want. I am proof that you can turn your le around after cancer. It doesn’t mean it’s the end. You can still reach your goals and dreams.

Its Meghan Markles first Christmas as a royal, and she is set to join the family to watch the Queens speech.But there is one very important member who wont be present, according to former royal butler Paul Burrell.He says the Queen hates watching herself on TV and so takes herself off for a walk instead.The Queens Speech will be played at pm, they go through the saloon drawing room and switch the TV on, people will be expected to be there, he told the Daily Mail.But the one person missing will be Her Majesty, who will slip through the north end door and go for a walk, as she doesnt like to watch herself. Then when shes back they will congratulate her saying: Oh, you were very good this year Granny. Well done.  Burrell told how everything works like clockwork at Sandringham, with all the festivities timed and organised - including drinks, lunch and games. He said the Queen loves having the entire family together and all members are expected to attend the activities.Burrell also said there will be a seating plan for lunch and royals should make polite chat with whoever they end up sitting next to. Speaking about what he thinks a good Christmas present for the Queen is, Burrell revealed she likes books - including thrillers.Hundreds of fans gathered at the Queens Sandringham estate to catch a glimpse of pregnant Meghan, husband Prince Harry and fellow royals. The Duchess of Sussex celebrates with her in-laws for a second time - but the first time as an official member of the royal family after marrying Prince Harry in May.

title: queens christmas speech leaked youtube
story: NewsQueens Christmas speech LEAKED on YouTube hours before it airs on TVA five-minute, -second clip showing the Queens address has surfaced on social media and websitesShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video what-exactly-queens-christmas-speech-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Queens entire Christmas speech has been leaked online hours before millions sit down to watch it on TV. A five-minute, -second clip was posted on YouTube and shared on a number of websites and social media accounts. It emerged as the Royal Family prepared for its annual Christmas Day service at the -year-old Queens Sandringham country estate in Norfolk. Buckingham Palace has kept the speech a secret, releasing a photo of the Queen sat in her lavish White Drawing Room and a few excerpts of what she said in the recording. It will be shown on TV at pm. According to Buckingham Palace, the Queen will say in her Christmas message that the festivals message of peace and goodwill needs to be heeded as much as ever, and people should respect each other even when they harbour the most deeply held dferences.  She will also speak of family and friendship following a year in which her grandson Prince Harry married US-born actress Meghan Markle, who is pregnant with the couples first child. Speaking about the birth of Jesus, she will say: I believe his message of peace on earth and goodwill to all is never out of date. It can be heeded by everyone its needed as much as ever. Even with the most deeply held dferences, treating the other person with respect and as a fellow human being is always a good step towards greater understanding.  She will also say: Through the many changes I have seen over the years, faith, family and friendship have been not only a constant for me but a source of personal comfort and reassurance. Buckingham Palace declined to comment on the leak.has chosen not to reveal details that were not officially released through the Palace. The Queen issued a writ against The Sun after it published the full text of her  broadcast two days before transmission. She later accepted an apology and a pound, donation to charity. Her Christmas broadcast is a traditional feature of the festive season where the head of state can express her thoughts about the past year.  The monarch made her first Christmas broadcast live on the radio in  - the year of her accession - and the annual message was first shown on TV in . She has made a Christmas Day speech every year except in , when she decided the royals had been on TV enough after an unprecedented family documentary. Instead, her greeting took the form of a written address. The first televised broadcast was transmitted live from the Long Library at Sandringham, and the Queen told how she hoped this new medium will make my Christmas message more personal and more direct. The Queens first pre-recorded speech was in .   The monarch usually completes her delivery in one take. The Queens grandfather, King George V, delivered the first royal Christmas broadcast live on the radio from Sandringham in . He read a message composed by author Rudyard Kipling. The original idea was suggested by Sir John Reith, the founding father of the BBC, to inaugurate the Empire Service, now the BBC World Service. The speech is written by the Queen herself and is one of the rare occasions when she does not turn to the Government for advice and is able to voice her own views. Each message has a strong religious framework and reflects current issues. She chooses a theme, drawing sometimes on her own personal experiences and sometimes from global events such as wars, terrorist attacks or natural disasters.

title: queens christmas speech meghan markle
story: NewsQueens Christmas speech shows off family snaps - and Meghan Markle has top spotHeres a breakdown of everything going on around the -year-old Queen in her Christmas speech to the nationShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video what-exactly-queens-christmas-speech-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Queen is surrounded by portraits of her family as she delivers her Christmas speech in the White Drawing Room of Buckingham Palace - but three in particular feature prominently. A photo released ahead of her speech reveals the -year-old monarchs special table of photos of her grandchildren and their spouses. One photo next to the Queen features Prince William and Kate and their children, Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, and Prince Charles and Camilla. A side table in the background is decorated with a stunning portrait of Harry and Meghan on their wedding day last May. Heres a breakdown of everything going on around the Queen as she recorded her speech, which airs on Christmas Day.   . Ivory silk cocktail dressThe Queens ivory silk cocktail dress was designed by her senior dresser Angela Kelly. It has a pastel blue, white and gold lameacute lace overlay. The Queen recorded her speech two weeks ago in the White Drawing Room, delivering a message of peace and goodwill. The White Drawing Room is one of the more intimate State Rooms at Buckingham Palace. It us used for Christmas broadcasts, formal family photos and for key guests to be presented to the Queen. The Queen enters via a hidden door disguised as a mirror and cabinet.   . Prince Philips gt The Queen wore a Scarab brooch given to her by her -year-old husband, Prince Philip, in . Designed by the late Andrew Grima, it is made of yellow gold with a carved ruby and diamond embellishments. It is said to be her favourite brooch, as shes been pictured wearing it many times over the decades. . Queen Victorias gilded piano The stunning gilded piano by SP Erard was made for Queen Victoria and her husband Prince Albert in . It was intended as a showpiece for the State Rooms at Buckingham Palace. The gilded case is in the French early th century style with decorations including cherubs and singeries, and comical scenes involving monkeys playing musical instruments and making mischief.   . Prince Charles as a baby There are three photos to the Queens immediate right. One shows her - then Princess Elizabeth, aged  - and Philip holding baby Charles in April , when he was about five months old. The Prince of Wales celebrated his th birthday last month. . Future King George V The Queens table also features a photo of her father, the future King George V, when he was known as Prince Albert. Albert is wearing his naval unorm around the time he was serving on the HMS Collingwood during the naval Battle of Jutland in the First World War in . He became king when his brother, Edward VIII, abdicated in  so he could marry American socialite Wallis Simpson. Princess Elizabeth became Queen when George V died in February . . Prince Charles family Between the photos of Charles as a baby and Prince Albert is a th birthday portrait of the Princes of Wales and his family.He is sat next to his we Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, with Prince George on his lap and Princess Charlotte with Camilla. Behind them are Kate, the Duchess of Cambridge - holding Prince Louis - and Prince William, alongside Prince Harry and Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, who is pregnant with the couples first child. In the photo of the Queen delivering her Christmas speech, the glow of a lamp is reflected in the glass frame of the family portrait.   . Princess Eugenies wedding photo Off to the side is a table with three portraits - including one of Princess Eugenie and her husband Jack Brooksbank with their page boys and bridesmaids on their wedding day in October. It was taken in the White Drawing Room at Windsor. The page boys and bridesmaids include Prince George and Princess Charlotte, Isla Phillips and Mia Tindall, and Theodora Williams, the daughter of pop star Robbie Williams and we Ayda Field.  . Prince Harry and Meghan Markle The third photo on the table is a stunning snap of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle on their wedding day on May . It was taken by professional photographer Alexi Lubomirski on the East Terrace of Windsor Castle, with Meghan wearing a Givenchy gown. The wedding was watched by tens of millions of people around the world, making it one of the most watched events of .   . Christmas card from William and Kate The Duke and Duchess of Cambridges Christmas card features a casual photo of the couple and their children. It is the first to feature Prince Louis following his birth in April. The photo was taken by professional photographer Matt Porteous at the Cambridges country home at Anmer Hall, Norfolk. . Sappho The marble sculpture of the Ancient Greek poet Sappho was made by William Theed, who was patronised by Queen Victoria and Prince Albert. His works are found throughout Buckingham Palace and Victorias Isle of Wight retreat, Osborne House. Sappho wrote poems which were set to music played on a lute, which she holds in her left hand. . Giant Christmas tree Behind the gilded piano is a massive Christmas tree decorated with baubles and lights. Queen Charlotte, the German-born we of George III, is credited with introducing the Christmas tree to the UK. She decorated an evergreen tree for the Royal Family as early as the s, using candles, paper flowers and sweets.

story: NewsQueens speech in front of lavish gold piano blasted for being out of touchQueen Elizabeth referred to Brexit in her Christmas day message as she sat beside a golden pianoShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video queen-delivers-christmas-message-human-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Queens Christmas Day speech has been slammed on social media for being out of touch and disrespectful to families struggling to make ends meet. In her annual address, broadcast at pm today. the head of state talked about Brexit and austerity. But she also praised the Comonwealth for the bonds of affection it promotes, and a common desire to live in a better, more peaceful world. Even with the most deeply held dferences, treating the other person with respect and as a fellow human being is always a good first step towards greater understanding. The royal joked about being a grandmother and looking forward family weddings. But the Queen was branded out of touch by viewers as the -year-old monarch delivered her speech beside a lavish golden piano in a luxurious room at Buckingham Palace. Some commentators pointed out the vast disparity between the Queens opulence and the real-le situations of her subjects as she called for people to come together no be riven by tribalism.   One posted on Twitter: Always warms an old republican’s heart to see the billionaire head of an antiquated institution, surrounding themselves with gold in their modest -roomed detached home, while others are f***ing struggling to make ends meet. Others highlighted the plight of food bank users over Christmas, with one writing: Queen says, from her humble and modest surroundings, family kept her well occupied over the year. I suspect the thousands of mums and dads that use food banks and struggle on Universal Credit each week could say the same. And one Twitter user said: I dont understand the criticism old Mrs Windsor is getting over her gold piano while she lectures her subjects. Its a fairly standard piece of furniture. I keep mine next to my diamond encrusted microwave.   One man posted: Child poverty is at a modern high and Old Queen Lizzy is telling us all to stick together with her big gold piano and pound million loft conversion paid by her struggling people. Others called the message pathetic, and dire. The Queen’s private net worth is thought to be around poundmillion, according to the Sunday Times. Her reign as monarch has lasted  years and she has been married to the Duke of Edinburgh for more than seven decades. She was, earlier today, at the traditional Christmas Day service at the church at Sandringham. THE HISTORY OF THE PIANO Queen Victoria and Prince Albert installed pianos in the private apartments of all their residences. Together they played arrangements of overtures and symphonies, and accompanied each other in song. This particular elaborately decorated instrument was intended as a showpiece for the State Rooms at Buckingham Palace.  The gilded case is decorated in the French early eighteenth-century style with cherubs and singeries – comical scenes involving monkeys playing musical instruments and making mischief. Queen Victoria had owned a piano decorated in a similar manner almost twenty years earlier. In her diary of  March , she wrote, Lord Melbourne admired the new painted piano I have in the drawing-room, and said, I like those monkeys on it. The piano, an S  P Erard, was first purchased by Queen Victoria in . It is made of mahogany, satinwood and pine, with brass and gilt bronze mounts, gilded and nished. It is decorated with elaborate oil scenes on the lids and sides and finished off with a nish. It underwent a major restoration with cleaning and repair prior to featuring in a Victoria and Albert exhibition which was held in The Queen’s Gallery in .  The restoration was mainly to remove substantial dirt from the two main lids and the upper surfaces, and to restore nish. According to the Royal Collection trust, it measures .cm x . x .. Erard was founded by Seacutebastien Erardwho started out making pianos for the French nobility The firm passed through the generations of the Erard family, which opened a London premises in . When Pierre Erardran the London business the firm won a gold medal at the  Paris Exposition and became piano maker to Albert, Prince Consort - husband of Queen Victoria. The piano is stamped with the serial number . The Royal Collection Trust describes the surface as painted by Franccedilois Rochard in polychrome colours with singeries and Berainesque mots. The mouldings and rim of the piano are bronze, chased and gilt. It is supported on three incurving cabriole legs of gilded wood with heavy floral garlands and carved at the top with two scrolls flanking a prominent flower. Pedal section in form of lyre in gilded wood with foliate decoration.

title: watch queens christmas speech jokes
story: NewsWatch Queens speech in full for Christmas  as she jokes about Meghan and HarryThe Queen reflected on family milestones - including the weddings of Meghan Markle and Prince Harry and Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank, and the arrivals of Prince Louis and Zara Tindalls daughter LenaShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video queen-delivers-christmas-message-human-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Queen used her Christmas Day broadcast to say the Christian message of “peace on Earth and goodwill to all” is needed “as much as ever”. With parliament deeply ided over Theresa May’s Brexit deal and military conflicts still raging in parts of the world, the monarch’s words are likely to resonate with many. She also joked about being a grandmother in her Christmas Day message, saying family events like the wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, and births have kept her well occupied this year. But she also highlighted the darker side of le, how religious faith which can lead people to do good in the service of others can also fall victim to tribalism. Her speech was broadcast at pm - but it was mysteriously leaked hours earlier on YouTube.  Politicians on all sides have engaged in bitter wrangling for weeks as the date for Britain leaving the EU – March  next year – draws ever closer. In the broadcast, recorded in Buckingham Palace’s White Drawin Room, the monarch said: “I believe his message of peace on Earth and goodwill to all is never out of date. It can be heeded by everyone it’s needed as much as ever.” During her address the -year-old monarch also highlighted the importance of people with strongly opposing views bridging the gap between one another, by being civil and acting with common decency. In a more light hearted moment, the Queen joked about being a grandmother in her Christmas Day message, saying family events like weddings and births have kept her “well occupied” this year.  And she thanked members of the armed forces, many of whom will be deployed overseas at Christmas, for their efforts. The Queen has had a memorable , with two of her grandchildren - the Duke of Cambridge and Zara Tindall - welcoming new additions to their families. Another grandson, Prince Harry, married Meghan Markle and they became the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, announcing soon afterwards that were expecting their first child, due in the spring. Granddaughter Princess Eugenie wed long-term boyfriend Jack Brooksbank.  Footage of Harry and Meghans glittering wedding was featured in the broadcast alongside Eugenie and Jacks nuptials, and also the moments when the couples kissed on the steps of St Georges Chapel at Windsor Castle. The Duke and Duchesss carriage ride was also screened. Bringing a touch of humour to her televised address, the Queen, surrounded by family photos, said: “Closer to home, it’s been a busy year for my family, with two weddings and two babies and another child expected soon. “It helps to keep a grandmother well occupied.” She also described the importance of having loved ones around her: “Through the many changes I have seen over the years, faith, family and friendship have been not only a constant for me but a source of personal comfort and reassurance.”  And she offered words of comfort for those missing relatives or friends: “At Christmas, we become keenly aware of loved ones who have died, whatever the circumstances. “But, of course, we would not grievewe did not love.” The first of the two royal babies to arrive this year was Louis, and there was a clip of his proud parents, William and Kate, presenting him to the world outside the private Lindo Wing of St Marys Hospital, Paddington, where he was born on April . And in June, Zara and husband Mike Tindall, a former England rugby player, welcomed their second child - a daughter called Lena.  We have had other celebrations too, including the th birthday of the Prince of Wales, said the Queen as the camera panned to a framed picture on her desk, an official image released to mark Charless milestone and featuring his we, the Duchess of Cornwall, along with the Cambridges and their children, and the Sussexes. The Queen also remembered her father, George VI, reflecting on his service with the Royal Navy during the First World War and the role he played in the early years of the Commonwealth. During the speech, the Queen was surrounded by family photos, including William and Kates Christmas card image featuring themselves and their children, a picture from Eugenies wedding showing the bride and groom surrounded by their bridesmaids and pageboys, a black and white image from Harry and Meghans big day, and a picture of George VI. The Queen hosted the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in London in April and she noted that eight states attended the first such gathering in  and were welcomed by her father.  She added that today the Commonwealth consists of  member countries with a combined population of . billion. She said: Its strength lies in the bonds of affection it promotes, and a common desire to live in a better, more peaceful world. Even with the most deeply held dferences, treating the other person with respect and as a fellow human being is always a good first step towards greater understanding. As head of state, the Queen remains publicly neutral when it comes to political matters and does not express her views on issues. But some commentators may interpret her words about respecting others who hold opposing views as a veiled reference to the toxic mood of the public debate around Britain leaving the EU. Now aged , the Queens reign as monarch has lasted  years and she has been married to the Duke of Edinburgh for more than seven decades.  Sitting at a desk and with a Christmas tree in the background, she said: Some cultures believe a long le brings wisdom. Id like to think so. Perhaps part of that wisdom is to recognise some of les baffling paradoxes, such as the way human beings have a huge propensity for good, and yet a capacity for evil. Even the power of faith, which frequently inspires great generosity and self-sacrice, can fall victim to tribalism. After footage was shown of a thrilling RAF fly-past, celebrating the air forces centenary by forming the number , the Queen said: We owe them and all our armed services our deepest gratitude. She also acknowledged the sacrices of the thousands of seamen who died fighting in the First World War Battle of Jutland in  during which her father served as a midshipman. She said: The British fleet lost  ships and , men in that engagement. My father wrote in a letter: How and why we were not hit beats me. Like others, he lost friends in the war. The Queen concluded her broadcast by highlighting Jesus’s message, often cited at this time of year: “I believe his message of peace on earth and goodwill to all is never out of date. “It can be heeded by everyone it’s needed as much as ever. A very happy Christmas to you all.” The broadcast ended as it had begun, with singing from the choir of King’s College, Cambridge, famous, as the Queen said, for its Nine Lessons and Carols. They opened the festive broadcast by singing the National Anthem and ended with the carol Once In Royal David’s City. The broadcast was recorded on December  before Prime Minister and Jeremy Corbyns angry Commons clash which, with Brexit at its root, saw the Labour leader accused of calling Theresa May a stupid woman, something he denied. The speech in full For many, the service of Nine Lessons and Carols from Kings College, Cambridge, is when Christmas begins. Listened to by millions of people around the world, it starts with a chorister singing the first verse of Once in Royal Davids City. The priest who introduced this service to Kings College chapel, exactly one hundred years ago, was Eric Milner-White. He had served as a military chaplain in the First World War. Just six weeks after the Armistice, he wanted a new kind of service which, with its message of peace and goodwill, spoke to the needs of the times. Twenty eighteen has been a year of centenaries. The Royal Air Force celebrated its th anniversary with a memorable fly-past demonstrating a thrilling unity of purpose and execution. We owe them and all our Armed Services our deepest gratitude. My father served in the Royal Navy during the First World War. He was a midshipman in HMS Collingwood at the Battle of Jutland in . The British fleet lost  ships and , men in that engagement. My father wrote in a letter: How and why we were not hit beats me. Like others, he lost friends in the war. At Christmas, we become keenly aware of loved ones who have died, whatever the circumstances. But, of course, we would not grievewe did not love. Closer to home, its been a busy year for my family, with two weddings and two babies, and another child expected soon. It helps to keep a grandmother well occupied. We have had other celebrations too, including the th birthday of The Prince of Wales. Some cultures believe a long le brings wisdom. Id like to think so. Perhaps part of that wisdom is to recognise some of les baffling paradoxes, such as the way human beings have a huge propensity for good, and yet a capacity for evil. Even the power of faith, which frequently inspires great generosity and self-sacrice, can fall victim to tribalism. But through the many changes I have seen over the years, faith, family and friendship have been not only a constant for me but a source of personal comfort and reassurance. In April, the Commonwealth Heads of Government met in London. My father welcomed just eight countries to the first such meeting in . Now the Commonwealth includes  countries with . billion people, a third of the worlds population. Its strength lies in the bonds of affection it promotes, and a common desire to live in a better, more peaceful world. Even with the most deeply held dferences, treating the other person with respect and as a fellow human being is always a good first step towards greater understanding. Indeed, the Commonwealth Games, held this year on Australias Gold Coast, are known universally as the Friendly Games because of their emphasis on goodwill and mutual respect. The Christmas story retains its appeal since it doesnt provide theoretical explanations for the puzzles of le. Instead its about the birth of a child and the hope that birth , years ago brought to the world. Only a few people acknowledged Jesus when he was born. Now billions follow him. I believe his message of peace on earth and goodwill to all is never out of date. It can be heeded by everyone its needed as much as ever. A very happy Christmas to you all.

title: what christmas presents politicians deserve
story: NewsopinionWhat Christmas presents do politicians deserve  Kevin Maguire plays Santa ClausSanta Maguire gives out his Christmas gts to politicians from Donald Trump to Theresa May and Emmanuel Macron to Jeremy HuntShareCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  DEC Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChristmas is a time for families, celebrations, refshylections and, of course, gts. After a bad-tempered year in politics, the deserving and un-deserving are about to get what’s coming to them, as Santa Maguire hands out his Christmas presents to the good, the bad... and the ugly. For Chris “Failing” Grayling a jamming device after the Transport Secretary dropped laws to control drones. Gatwick’s grounded holidaymakers join a long queue demanding he be toppled. Jeremy Corbyn receives new lights for his bike and a map of Europe, to see that Brexit will cheat working families the most. Hankies are in order for serial liar Boris Johnson. title: after defeat by celtic dundee boss says this weeks games are the ones that really count
story: Moments after Dundee’s - defeat at Celtic Park, manager Jim McIntyre’s thoughts turned straight to what he calls “two huge games” this week.The Dark Blues were condemned to spend Christmas as the Premiership’s bottom side after champions Celtic swept them aside with embarrassing ease.The Dens gaffer was disappointed with the manner of his side’s defeat but acknowledged this week’s games against Livingston and St Johnstone are where Dundee have a better opportunity to pick up some much-needed points.He said: “My whole thought process is we have two huge games coming up at home.“We need to make sure we are picking up points in these two games. They’ll be huge for us.”To add to the Dark Blues’ woes, St Mirren picked up a victory at Motherwell to leave them three points adrt at the foot of the ision.Adding points to his own team’s total is more important to Jim, however – as is bringing in new faces next month.“What St Mirren do isn’t our concern,” Jim added.“It’s all about what we do and we have to make sure we continue to just think about ourselves.“The transfer window is going to be important for all of the clubs at the bottom, it’s an opportunity to try to get players in to help the ones we already have.”The Dark Blues did hold out against a dominant Celtic for almost the entire first half with his team’s organisation pleasing the manager, though the manner of the opening goal didn’t.He said: “It was a deserved scoreline.“Celtic were very good, their movement was so fluid, they caused us loads of problems.“I thought our organisation defensively was very good for  minutes but concentration levels are so important.“The timing of the goal and our player stopping for offside was the key disappointment.“It was onside, our video boy confirmed at half-time it was onside, so that was disappointing, just play to the whistle and argue about it later.“A couple of minutes before half-time you’re looking to get in at - and regroup, try to address where Celtic were hurting us.“In the second half Celtic were just too good for us, simple as that.”

title: bin collection plans change for christmas
story: Councils across Tayside and Fe have announced changes to recycling schedules during the festive period.Dundee City Council carried out collections today – and will do so again on Hogmanay – as normal.However, all other collections will be running a day behind over the Christmas and New Year weeks.It means that collections planned for Tuesday will take place on Wednesday instead, with New Year’s Day collections put back until January .Collections will also be held on Saturday instead of Friday.The city council’s recycling centres will also have dferent opening hours.A spokesman said: “The recycling centres at Riverside and Baldovie will be closed tomorrow and Wednesday, and on Tuesday January  and Wednesday January .“The centres will be open am-.pm on all other days .“Please note a permit system is in place for certain types of vehicles.“The Riverside composting site will be closed tomorrow and Wednesday, and on Tuesday January  and Wednesday January .”Special waste uplts have been suspended until Monday January .In Angus the council says there will be no collections on Christmas Day, Boxing Day, New Year’s Day or January .Residents have been encouraged to visit the Angus Council website to check revised collection plans for specic addresses.Perth and Kinross Council will operate a similar scheme to the one in Angus, with collections suspended tomorrow and Wednesday and the same days next week, with information available on its website about revised collection plans.Fe Council’s bin collection schemes also dfer based on location, with residents able to download calendars from the council’s website which offer specic information about their address.

title: cafe staff doing their buttie at christmas to show dundee is an amazing place
story: A Dundee takeaway is to offer free food and drink to the less fortunate on Christmas Day.Butties  on Albert Street will be open for business at .am when it will hand out free soup, hot rolls, tea and coffee to people in need.Manageress Sharon Tait, , said the shop had been planning the gesture since November in an effort to give a little back to the community.She added: “This is the first year we have decided to do this.“I’ve always wanted to volunteer at the soup kitchens in Dundee over Christmas.“Having a young family that hadn’t always been possible but they’ve grown up now.“I spoke to our director Ian Tait, and he was up for doing it.“It will only be the Stobswell premises that will be open but four of us will be in until am.”Sharon said the response they’ve had to the shop opening has been excellent, with plenty of donations coming in from suppliers and other businesses.She added: “We’ve already had donations from the Booker Group, Broxburn Browns and Pam’s Flowers.“The post that was put up on social media was shared more than , times.“I have been overwhelmed by the response. There have been some great stories recently of people in the city helping others.“Dundee is an amazing place.”Ian said he was right behind the idea and is hopeful plenty of people will benefit.He added: “When Sharon approached us we thought it was an excellent idea.“We’ve had an incredible response but maybe not everyone will have social media.“If anyone knows someone who would benefit they should tell them that we are open and to come into the shop.”

title: community spirit meant charity could give kids a magic time for christmas
story: A charity which supports families across the city held its Christmas party – thanks to the backing of a number of local businesses and organisations.Home-Start Dundee, which helps families with young children with a range of challenges, enjoyed a festive knees-up at its base in the Central Baptist Church on Ward Road.Jane Whyte – of Nursery Rhymes on Brook Street, Broughty Ferry – organised a magician for the party. Buffet products were donated by Sam Will, the community champion at Asda in Kirkton.Downfield Musical Society arranged for Santa to pay a visit, with the gts he handed out coming from a wide range of local people.City firm Lee’s Tees and Keys handed over selection boxes for the charity to dish out.Meanwhile, presents were donated from the Cash for Kids initiative while shoeboxes were given to the charity by BT.A total of  families received bags of gts through Home-Start, including those who have visits in their homes from charity volunteers.A spokeswoman for Home-Start said: “We would like to thank everyone for their support – it is invaluable to families across Dundee.”

title: dundee united fans bid to raise funds for statue of legend jim mclean
story: The Dundee United Community Trust and Jim McLean Tribute Group have joined forces in a bid to raise funds to build a statue of the legendary manager.The groups handed out flyers at Saturday’s match with Falkirk as they look to pull together the necessary money for the design and production of a statue at Tannadice.A range of fundraising activities is set to be held in a bid to raise the cash required to pay a fitting tribute to the former boss.A Just Giving page has been set up for fans to donate, with the groups also planning to reach out to benefactors within the club and beyond.David Dorward, chairman of Dundee United Community Trust, said: “Dundee United Community Trust is delighted to support this project.”George Haggarty, chairman of the Jim McLean Tribute Group, added: “This is a great project.”

title: dundee united goalkeeper benjamin siegrist delighted to be working at christmas
story: His mates having been sending plenty reminders they are now on holiday while he’s working over the festive season but Dundee United goalie Benjamin Siegrist insists he’s the lucky one.Back home in Switzerland, players are now on holiday for Christmas and Siegrist has revealed a string of them haven’t been slow to let him know they’re enjoying putting their feet up.As he prepares for the festive programme that will see the Tangerines face Falkirk today and Alloa a week later, he insists he wouldn’t have it any other way.“I love it. I know what it is like over here from my time with Aston Villa,” he said.“In Switzerland last weekend it was the last game and now every one of my friends is on holiday. They are all sending me pictures so I block them on social media. I’m only kidding, for me it is just nice to be playing.“There is not one bit of jealously, I would rather be here and playing football over Christmas than be on holiday with them.“For me as a foreigner having been involved in the English game and now the Scottish game, I think it is beautul to be playing at this time of year.“You spend time with your family on Christmas Day but Boxing Day it is back into training to prepare for the next game and that’s what I like. We are playing today and then the th, there is no midweek game so it is perfect.“Listen, I live for playing football, I live and breathe football, so for me there is nothing better than having Christmas and then a game right away.”And, for Siegrist, the best Christmas presents he’ll get will be maximum points from Falkirk and Alloa.If United go about their business the way they did up at Inverness last weekend, he believes they will do exactly that.Although that Highland trip saw them have to fight back to earn a point, he believes the level of performance bodes well for what lies ahead in the league programme.“You never know what that point is worth until you finish the season, so that might be a very good one. However, the gaffer spoke about it to us during the week and the way we played compared to the week before at Morton was miles better.“That’s the way we want to play and we believe it gives us the best chance of winning every game or at least most of the games.“You are not going to walk through this league but we like to play with high tempo, pass the ball and cause problems for the opposition we can take advantage of. We just need to put it all together and get the three points.“We should be full of confidence the way we played last week because we know not every opposition can withstand the pressure we put on them.“It’s all about our performance, the way we go on the pitch and put into practice what we think we want to do.“The ability we have in the dressing-room, the characters we have, I think we have a really good team whether that’s in terms of spirit or ability.”After injury forced him off in the recent defeat against Ayr and forced him to miss the draw at Morton, Siegrist admits being recalled to the line-up last weekend was a boost for him.So far this term, one of his biggest battles has been to claim a starting place ahead of Matej Rakovan but that was an indication he’s now considered the first choice keeper by boss Robbie Neilson.“I’ve kind of over-extended when I was ing in the game against Ayr and it was a mixture between a knock and a muscle injury. It happens in football, you get injured sometimes and I was happy I was playing again as soon as I was back fit.”

title: everyone should be treated the same dundee boy kayden has a gift for giving
story: A Dundee primary school pupil has delved into his own pocket to prove he really does know the true meaning of Christmas.Nine-year-old Kayden Smith, from St Mary’s, who is a pupil at St Fergus RC Primary, has given up his own pocket money to buy food for people who are less well-off.He saved up £ a week and spent £ at the supermarket to help others during the festive period.Kayden said: “Every week for four weeks I went shopping with my grandma and bought food for other people who might be hungry. I decided that I should do this because I know that some people can’t afford to buy food and don’t have very much of their own.“I don’t like people having to feel like that so I thought I could use my pocket money to help them because I get plenty to eat.“I believe everyone should be treated the same and I thought this was the best way I could do something to help others less well-off then I am.”Kayden went to theof working out meal plans and decided to buy food that would cover breakfast, lunch and tea.“I bought things like porridge for breakfast, soup for lunch and tins of spaghetti bolognese and chicken curry for tea,” he said. “I got the curry because it’s my favourite and my mum makes the best chicken curry.”After he bought his groceries, Kayden would go to the food trolley in Asda Kirkton, where donations are collected and passed on to those who need them.He said: “I’m really happy to have been able to do it and I would do again another time.”Kayden’s gran Denise Smith, , said: “We are very proud of Kayden.“He thought this up all by himself and told me what he wanted to do and asked meI would help him. Every week, when I went round the supermarket with my trolley, Kayden would come along with his own trolley and select what he wanted to put in it.“He had carefully thought out meals and bought food for dferent times of the day. If one week he had money left over he saved it up for the next week so he had a little bit more to spend.”Denise said it wasn’t unusual for Kayden to want to help other people.She said: “If we go down the street and he sees someone sitting on the pavement he will often go up to them and give them some of his money.“That’s just how he is, and we are very proud of him. He’s told me he would like to do it again.”

title: five weeks of road closures ahead on key city route
story: Bus services and traffic are set to be heavily affected by a five-week-long phased closure of a busy city road.Claypotts Road will be closed in two stages during the -day maintenance scheme which will be undertaken by Tayside Contracts.The first phase will involve the street being closed off between Albert Road and Victoria Road.In the second phase of works, Claypotts Road will be closed between Victoria Road and Arbroath Road.Disruption is likely for public transport and motorists as the works will cut off a major link between the north and south of Broughty Ferry and could lead to a rise in traffic on neighbouring streets such as Seafield Road, Cedar Road and Forthill Road.Works will start on Monday January  and the contractor hopes to complete the programme by Sunday February .Ferry Liberal Democrat councillor Craig Duncan said those using the route should plan for the works.“The road does need a bit of TLC and I always say there’s never a good time to do these things – it’s a question of being patient,” he said.“The usual advice applies –you can, avoid the area and give yourself a bit of extra time when you’re leaving the house.”The road is used by Xplore Dundee and Stagecoach East Scotland. Services likely to be affected include the ,  A, , A C and the A C.Passengers are advised to check with the firms, or Traveline Scotland, ahead of their journey.Dundee City Council said ersions will be in place during the works, but is yet to publish details of its plans.A spokeswoman for the local authority said: “These roadworks are part of an ongoing roads maintenance programme across the city.“Arrangements for traffic will be in operation during the works and these will be signposted for motorists.”

title: locked out 31 council tenants shown the door after running up 100k of rent arrears
story: Almost £, in rent arrears was owed to Dundee City Council from people evicted this year.New figures reveal that dozens of people were evicted from their properties across the city.The council showed the door to  tenants in  – compared with  the previous year.All of those removed from their homes were in arrears with their rent.Figures revealed by the council in response to a freedom of which covers Stobswell and areas north of the city centre.However, the figure of  represented a drop of one case from  last year.The DD postcode, which takes in the Lochee ward, topped last year’s eviction list with  but that fell to  for this year.There were six eviction cases in the DD postcode – which covers the east of Dundee – compared with  in .Only two cases were reported in the DD
