title: former-tranent-infant-school-building-set-to-be-brought-back-into-use
story: Concerns have repeatedly been raised about the future and condition of the former Tranent Infant School.However, East Lothian councillor Colin McGinn gave the townrsquos community council some good news when he confirmed it would be brought back into use.Mr McGinn, who lives in the town, said: ldquoWe have got confirmation about the infant school.ldquoIt is going to form part of the early years provision going forward, we have managed to confirm that.ldquoWhether it is nursery or early primary, it is going to be secured for that area of work.East Lothian Council officials are now working on a report on what can be done with the building, off Sandersonrsquos Wynd.Mr McGinn stressed there was ldquono timescale for when any work could take place but was pleased to see progress being made.He said: ldquoI think it is a great move. It is an iconic building in Tranent and one that nobody wanted to see it disused for as long as it has been.ldquoSome of us have been involved for a long time trying to resurrect it.ldquoIrsquom really pleased it will be early years and to have the sound of kids running about there again. It will be a real boost for that area.The building has lain empty and unused for more than a decade, with the school shutting in .Since then it has proven a popular gathering place for youths in the area and has regularly been targeted by vandals.Mr McGinn said there would be further barriers to overcome before the building was welcoming children again.He added: ldquoThe next hurdle will be finding money.However, he was confident that with a use identied for the building, which has CCTV to try to deter potential vandals, money could be found.He added: ldquoIrsquom really glad it is not getting knocked down or being a lump of concrete anymore.ldquoIt is an iconic building and a lot of people have family that were educated there.ldquoThe fact it is going to continue to educate our young folk through early years I think is the right thing for the building.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed they were looking to utilise the building in the future but stressed that no final decision had been taken on its use.She said: ldquoDiscussions and options for the future use of the former Tranent Infant School have put forward housing and education as the lead choices.ldquoThe preferred option currently appears to be for the use for early years and childcare expansion but a full report is currently being compiled and will be presented to a full council meeting for decision.

title: new-landlord-takes-over-at-the-prestoungrange-gothenburg
story: Michelle Wilson began working at The Goth public house on Prestonpans High Street a couple of years ago and very quickly rose through the ranks to become the general manager, under Sean Woodrsquos leadership.Sean said: ldquoMichelle became very evidently a huge asset to the business soon after she started.ldquoShe clearly has the drive, ambition and passion to make the best out of anything she puts her hands to.ldquoThe businessrsquo entertainment programme has grown signicantly since Michelle took it on and we have become a true destination for those seeking out weekend entertainment.Sean will be moving on to spend more time on other ventures, while Michelle will take on the lease and roll out a plan of improvements and initiatives to take the establishment to the next level.Sean added: ldquoIrsquove done what I can here and itrsquos now time to pass the baton on to somebody  to take things forward and seek out new ways of enhancing what is on offer at The Goth, and I couldnrsquot think of anybody better than Michelle to do just that.ldquoIt seems such a natural transition.ldquoI have found it an absolute pleasure to serve the community during my tenure, having presided over seven weddings, numerous family occasions and events, and have a huge gratitude of praise for Michelle having stood by my side throughout this time.ldquoI wish her all the best for the future.The Goth has changed hands a few times over the  years it has been in existence, the most signicant of which was when Dr Gordon Prestoungrangersquos family purchased and refurbished the building in  they have retained ownership ever since.An attempt to encourage a community buyout two years ago did not come to fruition, at which point Sean took on the lease of the establishment, having been the resident brewer for a year. Michelle took over the reins last month.She said: ldquoThis is an excellent opportunity that Irsquoll grab hold of with both hands.ldquoI love this place and everything about it. Our customers are an absolute pleasure to deal with and no two days are the same.ldquoThere is definitely something special about The Gothenburg and I have some incredible memories since Irsquove been here and am looking forward to creating many more. This isnrsquot just a bar and microbrewery itrsquos been a key community hub for nigh on  years now.ldquoWe have so many groups that use this place as their base, as well as my large group of regulars who come here not only for a bit banter with the staff but to meet up with friends, enjoy our live music and dine with their families.Dr Gordon Prestoungrange said: ldquoWe look forward to The Gothenburg continuing to offer the community a place where they can spend time with friends and family under Michellersquos leadership. Michelle has impressed us with her enthusiasm and energy.ldquoShe has clearly made a signicant contribution during her time as the general manager and before and comes highly recommended not only by Sean but by countless members of the community who have taken the time to show their support for her.ldquoSean has made some excellent improvements to the establishment and it continues to benefit from its outstanding legacy and reputation.ldquoMichelle will continue to ensure The Gothrsquos role in the community and will stand by the ethos upon which it operates: supporting the arts, community groups and the wider community, not just of Prestonpans, but East Lothian.

title: kind-tranent-youngster-collects-50-bags-of-foodbank-donations
story: Ten-year-old Archie Strang was joined by school friend Lucas Leishman on Saturday morning in collecting food from neighbours in the Bankpark area.The youngster, in P at Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School, posted letters through neighboursrsquo doors highlighting his upcoming collection for East Lothian Foodbank.His mum Heather was delighted with the response. She said: ldquoIt went really well and we got over  bags of food. We dropped them off at Tranent Library and they were delighted and are going to get them to the foodbank.Residents near Archiersquos home were asked to donate items ranging from mince pies and biscuits to bread sauce, tinned carrots and sweetcorn and Christmas pudding.Among those doing their bit was Councillor Kenny McLeod, who described the youngster as ldquoa wee star.He said: ldquoIt was great, absolutely fantastic. He did it last year as well as this year. I take my hat off to the wee guy.Ahead of the collection, Archie told the Courier: ldquoI was wanting to do it because of all the people that do not have money and need food.ldquoA lot of people at Christmas cannot celebrate like us and quite a lot of them have to go hungry and donrsquot have the same joy as us.ldquoI wanted to do it, not to be a hero, but I was trying to do it so that everyone could be happy around Tranent and to try to encourage other kids to do being doing it too.Peter Dicker, foodbank manager, said: ldquoIt is a wonderful effort by young Archie.

title: extension-plans-for-knox-academy-to-cope-with-new-homes
story: The townrsquos secondary school is currently home to  pupils and more than  full-time equivalent members of staff.However, those numbers would likely swellplans for a further  homes at Letham Mains get the go-ahead.East Lothian Council has confirmed that a school extention will be required in the coming years.Plans for the new  homes, off Pencaitland Road, were revealed at the beginning of October.Developers Taylor Wimpey East Scotland Mactaggart  Mickel Homes will now weigh up feedback from a public exhibition before deciding whether to submit a formal planning application to East Lothian Council.Currently, work is under way on more than  new homes at Letham Mains. The site will also be home to a new primary school, with work due to start soon.That primary school, which has provisionally been named Letham Primary School, will only cater for children within Letham Mains, with youngsters in the nearby Gateside and Dovecot developments going to the newly merged Haddington Primary School.However, there are no plans for a new secondary school, with pupils in the area all heading to Knox Academy.Paul Darling, a planning liaison officer at Haddington and District Community Council, was among those attending the display.He had concerns about how the new housing would impact upon the high school.He said the original plans for Letham Mains, which included the area of land now being considered for additional homes, suggested an extension to Knox Academy.But the plans were revised for fewer homes and the extension never materialised.Mr Darling called on East Lothian Council to confirm plans were in place for any necessary extension and let the public see them.The community councillor said: ldquoIf you look at Knox Academy, there is plenty of room for an extension. Someone could think out of the box, you have got all that car parking and you could build a school on the second level [above the car park]. There is lots of room without taking any of the playing space away. There is plenty of space for the extension to go in but there is no mention of it.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoAdditional pupil capacity and an expansion of Knox Academy will be required in the years ahead.ldquoAll the relevant developments in the catchment will make or have made contributions towards providing this additional capacity.ldquoThe timescale for requirement of the expansion is currently anticipated for , and so plans will be developed and confirmed in due course.

title: another-housing-development-planned-for-gullane
story: CALA Homes already has a number of housing sites in the village.Now it has applied for planning permission for  properties ndash including four lsquoaffordable homesrsquo ndash on land south-east of Fenton Gait.If the scheme is approved, the affordable homes would be contained within a single terraced property to the north of the site.Documents submitted to the councilrsquos planning department show that the proposed design has changed since the Fenton Gait South development was first mooted more than  months ago.The design and access statement with the council notes: ldquoThe design of the layout has evolved through the design process, through conversations with consultants and East Lothian planning department.ldquoThe most signicant change was establishing the outward-looking approach of the dwellings to ensure a positive outlook of development along the eastern edge of the village, and establishing the same principles of design approach that have been developed for the Saltcoats Field proposals.Already, CALA is involved in three other housing projects in the village.Work is well under way to transform the former Scottish Fire and Rescue Service college site into  properties.Meanwhile, to the south of the village at Saltcoats Field,  homes are planned, with permission given earlier this year. While  homes are being built at Fenton Gait East.A spokesman for CALA Homessaid: ldquoWersquore very proud to be playing our part in developing Gullane and providing much-needed homes in the town.

title: bonnie-baby-champions-win-to-benefit-local-charity
story: Cute little George Thomson-Tait claimed pound for his family after he was crowned the winner of the competition, which attracted thousands of votes from throughout the county.Proud mum Shannon Thomson was delighted to win and revealed her plans for the prize money.She said: ldquoI was actually thinking of donating it to a local drug charity that is close to my heart but I am going to split the money.ldquoIrsquom going to give pound to MELDand pound will go into Georgersquos bank account.George, who turns one on January , is not the first member of the family to win the competition.Shannon, of Tranent, told the Courier she had been inspired to enter him after a previous success.She said: ldquoMy niece, Felicity Thomson, won the competition about five years ago.ldquoShe won and my mum told me to put George in the competition as well.Friends and family all bought copies of the Courier and filled in the coupons to help George to be crowned the winner.He also had a helping hand from customers at Tranent Post Office, where his -year-old mum works.Her dad, George Thomson, was the townrsquos postmaster and is behind the redevelopment of the former Co-op building at the junction of Tranentrsquos High Street and Church Street.She described her son as ldquoa good baby, funny and always up to nonsense.

title: swimmers-take-a-christmas-day-dip-to-support-lifeboat-crews
story: The increasingly popular seasonal tradition saw beaches, coastal rocks and lake shores north and south packed with brave bathers.With hardy souls temporarily swapping turkey for trunks and Brussel sprouts for bikinis, events were staged from Portstewart Strand on the Causeway Coast to Myrtleville beach in Co Cork, and many spots in between.In Co Dublin, an annual swim to raise funds for the RNLI has been held by Clontarf Yacht and Boat Club for the past  years.Ian Sargent, , who has been raising cash throughout those four decades, said the event was stronger than ever.ldquoOur annual Christmas swim has been going from the s and it has been getting bigger every year, with more and more participation, he said.Mr Sargent stayed on dry land this year, insisting his winter dipping days were being him.ldquoI stopped that when I was , he laughed.Sailor Tom Leonard was among those who braved the waves.ldquoWe do this for the RNLI every year, itrsquos a great cause, they do great work and without them we wouldnrsquot be sailing on the sea, he said.Fellow swimmer John OrsquoReilly said the event had earned a reputation for the amount of money raised.ldquoForty two years ago we started swimming here and we raised the largest amount of money for the leboat in the British Isles, he said.ldquoAnd you can see by the crowd we are going to raise more money today.Orla Doogue, a member of the clubrsquos fundraising committee, highlighted her familyrsquos own debt of gratitude to leboat volunteers.ldquoThere were probably about  swimmers here all raising money for the RNLI, she said.ldquoMy aunt and uncle and my cousin, who all swam here today, were rescued earlier this year off Rathlin Island where there were two leboats called out to their assistance.Elsewhere in Dublin, hundreds again flocked to the rocks at the ever popular Forty Foot at Sandycove.Swimmers, many wearing Santa hats, laughed off the shivers as they lined up to jump into the chilly waters.December  has also become a popular day for sea swims off the island of Ireland and more events are due to take place on both sides of the border on St Stephenrsquos Boxing Day.

title: big-thumbs-blamed-after-scottish-mp-likes-risque-tweet
story: The Secretary of State for Scotland ldquoliked a tweet by American internet personality James Charles that said: ldquoall I want for christmas is a good d*** to s*** tbh.The Scottish Conservative MP for Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale later removed the ldquolike after it had gathered attention on the social media .He then tweeted: ldquoBig thumbs always a twitter issue at any time of year along with a Santa Claus emoji and a winking face.Big thumbs always a twitter issue at any time of year ##mdash David MundellDecember ,  columnist and Labour supporter Owen Jones replied: ldquoNever thought Irsquod say it but Happy Christmas and I hope your wish comes true!

title: objectors-to-parking-zones-outside-celtic-park-and-ibrox-stadium-invited-to-speak-at-public-hearing
story: A number of objections have been made against the proposals that include the introduction of permanent signs and road markings.A consultation was held after local residents and elected members complained about obstructive parking on game days.They claimed local supporters routinely block footways, pedestrian crossings, private driveways and cause safety issues at junctions.The emergency routes, that provide direct access for emergency services, are currently traffic coned on match days, but are said to be failing to stop people inappropriately parking.Detailed plans on the changes were published earlier this year following the consultation.They resulted in  objections and  notices of support being received in respect of the proposals for Ibrox Stadium and  objections and  notices of support were received in respect of the proposals for Celtic Park.Glasgow City Council has now written to the Scottish Government asking for an independent Reporter to be provided to manage the hearings.Dates and venues are still to be decided and the procedures for both will be determined by the independent Reporter.All objectors will be notied of the request for a public hearing in relation to the proposals they are concerned about and have until January  to lodge their intention to be heard at the relevant hearing.Other issues raised during the public consultation included public transport provision, the effect on supporters with health or mobility issues who do not have Blue Badge dispensation.

title: scotlands-insider-guide-11-of-the-best-christmas-walks
story: No matter which part of the country you live in, great walks with stunning views are right on the doorstep.And therersquos no better time to pull on your walking boots than over the festive period, especially the days between Christmas and New Year when cabin fever can all too easily set in.Scotland looks particularly beautul in winter, a fact I couldnrsquot fail to notice as I traversed the country to research Scotlandrsquos Insider Guides for this magazine. Over the last six months Irsquove walked for miles up and down high streets, through woodland, on beaches, up hills, learning about the history and culture of each place along the way.Yoursquove helped too, of course, sending excellent recommendations, hints and tips about places visit, trails to take, cafes to sample the scones in.With this in mind, Irsquove compiled  of the best walks from my travels, any of which would boost physical and mental health over the holidays. So, whether yoursquore looking for a short donder with family and friends, or a few hours of fresh air and solitude, wrap up warm and get out there.The Darn Walk, Dunblane to Bridge of AllanWhich ever way round you do it, this ancient pathway by the River Allan makes for an enjoyable amble at any time of year. It also passes through one of Robert Louis Stevensonrsquos favourite spots, which provided inspiration for Ben Gunnrsquos cave in Treasure Island.Local resident Judy Murray, mother of tennis champions Andy and Jamie, loves this walk. ldquoThe three-mile pathway, which dates back to Roman times, is one of my favourite things to do in Dunblane, she told us. ldquoIf you start at Dunblane Golf Club, you come out close to Bridge of Allanrsquos famous ice cream parlour, the Allan Cafe. Perfect! And you can always get the train back.The West Sands, St AndrewsOn a crisp winterrsquos day there are few places Irsquod rather be than walking along the uninterrupted beach and dunes of the West Sands. It takes a good couple of hours to walk from the Old Course towards Leuchars and Tentsmuir, and back.No matter what the weather this beautul stretch of sand is populated with dogwalkers, runners and kite surfers keen to blow away the cobwebs ndash its nearly always windy ndash and soak up the views, which are still remembered by many for their starring role in the closing credits to the Oscar-winning film Chariots of Fire.Afterwards, youll be ready for a cuppa. The cafeacute at the British Golf Museum , right next to the th hole of the Old Course, has great coffee, excellent scones and some of the best views in Scotland.Stonehaven to Dunnottar CastlePerched on a giant rocky headland that almost seems detached from the mainland, Dunnottar Castle is surely the most spectacular of all Scotlandrsquos coastal ruins.It takes around  minutes to walk from the town up the castle and back, and according to Esther Ballesteros, no visit to Stonehaven would be complete without doing it at least once. ldquoThe views are just amazing, she said. ldquoAlongside with the castle itself and the beautul clfs, Stonehaven War memorial is also really interesting. And itrsquos an easy route for people of all ages and abilities.The castle itselfis always worth exploring, as are the ancient rocks on which it sits, thought to be formed  million years ago.Linlithgow Palace and lochThis easy circular walk, which covers . miles and takes about an hour, is perfect for families and provides excellent wildle-spotting opportunities, despite being close to the town.Susan Knox had a weekend break in Linlithgow earlier this year. She said: ldquoI would always recommend a walk around the loch to blow the cobwebs away. Itrsquos one of the largest natural freshwater lochs in the area and offers unparalleled views of the palace.Nairn to CawdorNairn has much to offer visitors, not least its famously beautul beach. But Irsquove chosen this linear six-mile walk along the River Nairn to Cawdor, since it offers an alternative view of the town, and passes through some lovely countryside. It takes around two hours to get to the village, andyou have time, Cawdor Castle makes for a fascinating couple of hours. Time it right and you can get a bus back to Nairn.Two viewpoint walk, ObanThough its name means ldquolittle bay in Gaelic, Obanrsquos shoreline is expansive, as are the vistas to the mountains and islands beyond.This excellent four-mile, . hour walk explores the centre of town and takes in the promenade before climbing up to two excellent viewpoints: MacCaigrsquos Towerand Pulpit Hill.When you head back down into town, stop by at the Seafood Hutat the Calmac Pier for some of the freshest crab, mussels and scallops yoursquore ever likely to eat.Jedburgh to KelsoIf yoursquore looking for an all-day walk, this ancient tail through the rolling countryside of the Borders fits the bill perfectly.Get an early start for this -mile stretch of the Borders Abbeys Way, which takes in two rivers ndash the Tweed and the Teviot ndash the Waterloo Monument, Wallacersquos Tower and Roxburgh Castle. At the end of the walk sit the ruins of Kelso Abbey.End the day with a pint of IPA and a hearty burger in The Cobbleson Bowmont Street.Corrieshalloch Gorge, Wester RossAround  minutes from Ullapool sits one of the most spectacular sights in Scotland. Granted, yoursquoll need a good head for heights to get the most out of Corrieshalloch Gorge , which is .km inand m deep. The Victorian suspension bridge allows for dramatic tree-lined views of the River Droma as it plummets through waterfalls, while the surrounding woodland nature trails offer great walking and bird-spotting potential. If yoursquore lucky, you might even see a golden eagle. Allow around an hour for the walk. Go to nts.org.uk for more details.The Birks of AberfeldyThis lovely circular walk, immortalised in song by Robert Burns, remains one of the most popular walks in Perthshire. It can be steep in parts, but the gorge of the Moness burn, waterfalls and views across to Strathtay are more than worth the effort.Back in Aberfeldy, the Habitat Cafeacute, right on the Square, is the place to go for a tasty bowl of soup or coffee and cake.Tobermory to the lighthouseIf you happen to be on Mull over the festive season, be sure to pull on your wellies for this three-mile walk from the islandrsquos main town, through woods to the picturesque lighthouse at Rubha nan Gall. From there yoursquoll be rewarded with wonderful views over the water to Ardnamurchan.On your way back, pop into the excellent Tobermory Distilleryfor a tour and a dram.North Berwick to GullaneTreat yourself to a fish supper from North Berwick Fry on Quality Street, then work it off with a stunning three to four hour shoreline walk to neighbouring Gullane. The walk itself takes in around seven miles, but factor in some time for sandcastle-building and rock-polling, too, and yoursquove got the perfect days out. Be careful, however, to avoid high tide. When you reach Gullane, you can jump on the bus back to North Berwick.

title: kevin-mckenna-why-is-scottish-labour-determined-to-let-down-scotland
story: When the Tories spoke about Scotlandrsquos best interests being protected by the Union you sensed they actually believed this heart and soul. The word Unionist is included in the full title of their party and the historic privileges enjoyed by them and the cultural constituency they represented have all indeed flourished when Westminsterrsquos writ has run in its four constituent parts.This is not to say that they are anything less than fully Scottish, just that they believe Scotlandrsquos destiny to be forever entwined with the UK. Itrsquos merely one among many declarations of what it means to be Scottish and none the less valid for that and is characterised chiefly by an historic affectionnot love for what they understand Britishness to be.Thus, there was an honesty and integrity about the Scottish Toriesrsquo opposition to independence that was absent in much of the campaigning of Scottish Labour chiefs and their water-carriers on social media. This seemed to be fuelled less by any great love for the Union than by an implacable malevolence ndash sometimes approaching outright hatred ndash towards anything sponsored by the SNP. At times you formed an impression thatScottish independence was being proposed by wee green men emerging from a spaceship they would receive a fairer hearing in some Labour circles than anyone sporting a yellow and black rosette.The seeds of such bitterness were probably sewn in hundreds of Westminster and electoral campaigns keenly contested and with a signicant degree of rancour with the SNP. On these occasions it wasnrsquot the Tories who were threatening their influence and privileges but the SNP, even though they may have shared largely similar social agendas. Many simply couldnrsquot stomach the possibility of permitting what would be the ultimate triumph of the SNP evenit meant ignoring what their instincts were telling them: that Westminster was beginning to favour options for the rich in its economic policies and to re-direct any resultant working-class bitterness in the direction of immigrants.Even the most reactionary of Tory governments come to power on the back of working class votes. For this to occur, they must always have an assortment of familiar phantoms and usual suspects to hand and these must be leveraged by calls to national unity and security or the echoes of empire. Any notions Scottish Labour might have entertained about de-coupling from such a polity were swamped by antagonism towards the wretched SNP. They also fashioned a  narrative to conceal such narrow animosity. Thus, the lie that the referendum was nasty and isive and that Yes supporters despised the English became the distinguishing feature of their campaign.It was probably this, as much as anything , that formed the tipping point for many Labour supporters who, having signalled their rejection of such a dishonest narrative, were subsequently marginalised and made to feel like aliens in their own party. None of them have since ed to the Labour fold and this, more than anything  is why Labour in Scotland is a spent force with no immediate prospect of recovery.Foolishly, Richard Leonard, Labourrsquos latest leader in Scotland, continues to oppose independence while exhibiting no shred of original thinking on policy that might make his party attractive once more to the tens of thousands of its former supporters who have abandoned it.As Westminster takes a two-week holiday while the clock ticks towards a No-deal Brexit nothing in the behaviour of Labourrsquos UK leadership has done anything to inspire confidence either. In the last seven days Irsquove asked several Labour supporters to describe their partyrsquos Brexit strategy. No two answers were the same and all were marked by confusion. Any empathy they had previously felt with Jeremy Corbynrsquos policies on social justice has evaporated, largely on the perception that he has been found grievously wanting on this the biggest political issue of their lives. No leadership, no consistency, no courage and no conviction are the unorm verdict of Mr Corbynrsquos lamentable last two weeks at Westminster. By contrast, Theresa May, even in these her darkest dayshas displayed all of these attributes.The spectre of a No-deal Brexit now looms large and with it the real threat, which the UK Government has now admitted, of civil disorder. These and the exposure of Mr Corbynrsquos failure of leadership will test the propaganda unit of the Better Together campaign during the second referendum on Scottish independence.Once, it might have been a valid argument to insist that in a time of national crisis we must pull in the same direction. Butyou have been ignored and treated with contempt as Scotlandrsquos Government and Scotlandrsquos parliament have been in their efforts to help get a decent Brexit or even to mitigate its worst effects then such appeals are rendered worthless and hollow.In  Westminsterrsquos lurch towards reactionary and socially isive policies tipped many of us towards an independent Scotland. Such a hard right agenda also seemed to act as an accelerant for darker elements with racist agendas. More than four years later the England that many of us loved and admired is on the verge of capitulating to these forces and it looks like UK Labour has been fighting them with a peashooter.When it comes time to have our second referendum ndash and we will have it ndash there will be a moral dimension to consider for those who previously voted No and this will outweigh everything . For by this time Brexit and its process will have destroyed their once cherished economic arguments and their warnings of social ision.

title: scottish-labour-divided-on-proposal-for-early-holyrood-election
story: Lord Foulkes, a Labour peer, is trying to bring forward the next election to , but he is not being backed by the leadership of the Scottish party.In a dig at Foulkes, a Labour source said: "This isnt something we support. We do need to open up democracy so, for example, all Labour peers are now appointed on the basis they will campaign for the abolition of the Lords and its replacement with an elected second chamber."It can also be revealed that MSP James Kelly, a member of leader Richard Leonardrsquos shadow cabinet, proposed a memberrsquos bill on an early election, but he was rebuffed.Holyrood elections used to take place every four years, but the  term was extended to five years to avoid a clash with the  general election.The Scottish ElectionsAct  also extended the current term to  so that it did not overlap with any general election a year earlier.However, no Westminster poll is now scheduled for  and Foulkes, a former party MP and MSP, has introduced legislation in the House of Lords to ensure voters would go to the polls in  for Holyrood.His Bill is making its way through the Lords and it is understood a Scottish Labour MP will attempt to steer it through the Commons.Foulkes contacted the party leaders in Scotland for comment, but he said Leonard did not respond.It mirrors a proposal Kelly floated internally this year when he was the shadow cabinet secretary for finance and the constitution.The Herald on Sunday can reveal he tried to win support for a memberrsquos bill at Holyrood for a  election.Supporters of the plan believed the SNP was ided on their strategy for a second independence referendum and an early poll would destablise the Nationalists.Backers also argued that it would show the party had confidence in Leonard and would put First Minister Nicola Sturgeon on the back foot.The proposal was rejected and Leonardrsquos team is said to be unenthusiastic about an early election.Scottish Labourrsquos poll ratings have been dire this year and party strategists believe the leader needs more time to introduce himself to the public.However, a party insider said of Scottish Labourrsquos stance on the Foulkes legislation: "Holyrood elections should be every four years, andtheres an opportunity to get rid of the SNP sooner rather than later, we should take it."By not backing this Bill we look as weak as Jeremy Corbyn, who keeps delaying a vote of confidence in the Tories."Richards team may feel they need more time before the next election, having failed to increase his profile, but thats no excuse for inflicting another year of nationalism on the country."In an article last month, Leonard wrote about why he believed there should be a general election as soon as possible:ldquoTherersquos got to be a fresh approach to Brexit. My own view is the best way to achieve that is for there to be a general election. This is a political crisis and therersquos a growing prospect of it being a constitutional crisis. That propels us, in my view, in the direction of a general election.

title: Iain Macwhirter  Here   s what we missed while we were all bickering about Brexit
story: Everything  has been on hold.Had it not been for Brexit there would, I think, have been much more about the state of the NHS. I keep hearing of people having to go private because they canrsquot get elective surgery ndash thatrsquos hips and knees ndash without waiting in agony for a year. Therersquos been a crisis of recruitment, with GPs retiring early and medical staff ing to Europe because of Brexit. Health boards are going bust and Audit Scotland pronounced the Scottish NHS ldquofinancially unsustainable in October.The merger of social care and healthcare has not generated the economies of scale and integration many hoped for. Scotland will share in the extra pound billion for the NHS announced in the UK Budget ndash but that doesnrsquot really amount to much in a service that still uses fax machines and pagers.The Trussell Trust says that use of foodbanks has risen by more than % thanks largely to the new benefit system. Yet the Government has placed badly-needed reforms on hold as part of its no-deal Brexit planning. The Scottish Government has just taken on greater responsibility for welfare and is under intense pressure from charities to mitigate the impact of Universal Credit.Obsessed with Brexit, we all but forgot that there is a war going on in Europe: in the Donbass region of Ukraine. The Ukraine government recently imposed martial law prior to an expected crackdown on pro-Russian separatists.Meanwhile, Putin has placed hundreds of battle tanks on the border. Nato is reportedly supplying arms to the pro-Western Poroshenko government in Kiev, so any Russian invasion could ignite the most serious conflict in Europe since the Second World War.Then, out of the blue, Donald Trump pulls US troops out of Syria and we suddenly remember that wersquove given hardly a thought all year to whatrsquos been happening in the Middle East and the war against Isis. It is now recognised that allied bombing of Raqqa was just as deadly to civilians as the widely-condemned Russian bombing of Aleppo. Amnesty International says the British and US strikes may have amounted to war crimes.Donald Trump continued his trade wars in . Were it not for the Brexit blinkers wersquod probably be preparing to deal with the next economic recession, which many economists seem convinced is coming. There is now a deadly combination of Trump wars, overcapacity, and public and private debt weighing down the global economy. You may not have noticed but one of the biggest stock-market booms in history has just come to a crashing end.The focus is on the beef between China and America, but the situation in the European Union is not reassuring. There was a potentially disastrous standoff between the Italian populist government of deputy Matteo Salvini and the EU this month, which echoed the Greek crisis of . A sovereign debt crisis looms as Italian debt rises beyond % of GDP. Central banks have little in their armoury left to deal with another recession, after a full decade of zero interest rates and quantitative easing.The internet has destroyed most of the high street, the newspaper industry, terrestrial broadcasting and is now eating itself, with Google and Facebook mired in scandals over surveillance capitalism. The tech giants finally lost their progressive gloss in .Demands for greater regulation grew ever louder following revelations about Cambridge Analyticarsquos targeted advertising during the Brexit referendum. Much of this algorithmic activity was allegedly financed by ldquodark money from right-wing plutocrats. rsquos intrepid tech reporter, Carole Cadwalladr, claimed collusion between Brexiters and the Kremlin trying to destabilise our politics.However, it emerged this month that British intelligence spooks have been conducting their own psyops programme through a company registered in, of all places, Auchtermuchty. The Integrity Initiative has reportedly been enlisting journalists to help conduct a retaliatory social media campaign against the Kremlin. This seems to have mainly involved smearing Jeremy Corbyn and his communications director, Seumus Milne, as Kremlin shills. I can confirm that the Integrity Initiative hasnt approached me ndash yet.Meanwhile, China is becoming a huge player in the ldquocognitive-military complex as the new hybrid warfare is being called. The Communist state stands accused of all manner of digital jiggery-pokery, online warfare and industrial espionage. The FBI warned this month that the cybersecurity threat from China ndash spying, hacking and so forth ndash is worse than anything Putinrsquos Fancy Bears have been up to. The Chinese tech giant Huawei has been banned from selling its G mobile phone equipment to America, Canada and New Zealand because it is feared there could be security issues.A Huawei executive, Meng Wanzhou, was arrested by the Canadian government this month, provoking number of retaliatory detentions of Canadians by the Chinese.Huawei is now the biggest telecoms equipment company in the world and works hand-in-glove with the Communist regime, including on its seriously scary social engineering programmes: Social Credit. This assigns a digital trust score to every one of Chinarsquos . billion citizens, based on their behaviour under constant video surveillance. It is an algorithmic dictatorship, a true digital dystopia, straight out of Black Mirror.Therersquos no sign of the government wishing to emulate this here, though there have been some worrying developments, such as the proposals to make misogyny and other forms of behaviour illegal under hate crime laws.The police are now recording as ldquohate incidents jokes, abusive remarks and accusations of transphobia. It may not be long before our digital devices like Alexa are checking on whether or not we use hate speech in our homes ndash theyrsquore already said to be eavesdropping on us for commercial purposesAnd Scotland  Well, perhaps the greatest casualty of Brexit has been Scottish politics, which practically ground to a halt in . The Scottish Parliamentrsquos powers have been undermined by two Supreme Court rulings relating to Brexit.The Sewel Convention is no more, and the Scottish Government has been put firmly in its place over its Continuity Bill, which tried to oppose the ldquopower grab of responsibilities repatriated from Brussels. Westminster remains sovereign over all matters, and possesses ldquounqualied legislative power, as the Law Lords ruled.No-one is even talking of a Scottish independence referendum any more, since it would simply be rejected by the UK Government. Scotland is being dragged kicking and screaming out of the European Union, and there seems nothing Nicola Sturgeon can do about it.At least, not until the Brexit clusterburach is finally resolved.

Much of this algorithmic activity was allegedly financed by ldquodark money from right-wing plutocrats. rsquos intrepid tech reporter, Carole Cadwalladr, claimed collusion between Brexiters and the Kremlin trying to destabilise our politics.However, it emerged this month that British intelligence spooks have been conducting their own psyops programme through a company registered in, of all places, Auchtermuchty. The Integrity Initiative has reportedly been enlisting journalists to help conduct a retaliatory social media campaign against the Kremlin. This seems to have mainly involved smearing Jeremy Corbyn and his communications director, Seumus Milne, as Kremlin shills. I can confirm that the Integrity Initiative hasnt approached me ndash yet.Meanwhile, China is becoming a huge player in the ldquocognitive-military complex as the new hybrid warfare is being called. The Communist state stands accused of all manner of digital jiggery-pokery, online warfare and industrial espionage. The FBI warned this month that the cybersecurity threat from China ndash spying, hacking and so forth ndash is worse than anything Putinrsquos Fancy Bears have been up to. The Chinese tech giant Huawei has been banned from selling its G mobile phone equipment to America, Canada and New Zealand because it is feared there could be security issues.A Huawei executive, Meng Wanzhou, was arrested by the Canadian government this month, provoking number of retaliatory detentions of Canadians by the Chinese.Huawei is now the biggest telecoms equipment company in the world and works hand-in-glove with the Communist regime, including on its seriously scary social engineering programmes: Social Credit. This assigns a digital trust score to every one of Chinarsquos . billion citizens, based on their behaviour under constant video surveillance. It is an algorithmic dictatorship, a true digital dystopia, straight out of Black Mirror.Therersquos no sign of the government wishing to emulate this here, though there have been some worrying developments, such as the proposals to make misogyny and other forms of behaviour illegal under hate crime laws.The police are now recording as ldquohate incidents jokes, abusive remarks and accusations of transphobia. It may not be long before our digital devices like Alexa are checking on whether or not we use hate speech in our homes ndash theyrsquore already said to be eavesdropping on us for commercial purposesAnd Scotland  Well, perhaps the greatest casualty of Brexit has been Scottish politics, which practically ground to a halt in . The Scottish Parliamentrsquos powers have been undermined by two Supreme Court rulings relating to Brexit.The Sewel Convention is no more, and the Scottish Government has been put firmly in its place over its Continuity Bill, which tried to oppose the ldquopower grab of responsibilities repatriated from Brussels. Westminster remains sovereign over all matters, and possesses ldquounqualied legislative power, as the Law Lords ruled.No-one is even talking of a Scottish independence referendum any more, since it would simply be rejected by the UK Government. Scotland is being dragged kicking and screaming out of the European Union, and there seems nothing Nicola Sturgeon can do about it.At least, not until the Brexit clusterburach is finally resolved.

title: 18-of-the-most-exciting-and-affordable-scotch-whiskies-around-today
story: It sounds simple ndash as easy as making a cake ndash and, in essence, it is, but the finished product, a beautul glass of fine whisky, is a beguiling, mysterious, puzzling, wonderful creation.Earlier this year, I wrote an article on the opening of the new Macallan distillery on Speyside, and as part of it I needed to describe exactly what whisky meant to me. This is what I said:ldquoItrsquos friendship and memory, wonderful moments and the emotions that go with them ndash the perfect partner to unforgettable events in all our lives.ldquoIt is the heady night my first daughter was born, when I arrived home from hospital and poured an Old Fettercairn to make a joyful, tearful toast to my we and tiny new baby.ldquoOr the bright May evening outside the Kingrsquos House in Glen Coe after my friend and I had climbed Agagrsquos Groove on the Buachaille Etive Mor. We shared a hip flask of Springbank as we stared up at the mountain, and it was the best Irsquod ever tasted.ldquoIt is the evenings around my kitchen table with my pal from across the road, music playing a little bit too loud into the wee small hours as the whisky and stories and laughter flow.ldquoThese moments, these images of times to treasure, that ability to create wonderful memories. That is, at the absolute basic, the essence of whisky.People often say that something is greater than the sum of its parts ndash well, that phrase could have been coined especially for Scotlandrsquos national drink.Since I first fell in love with whisky in , Irsquove been lucky enough to try some unforgettable drams ... including one or two whose price tag ran into five figures.But over the years itrsquos become clear to me that you donrsquot have to pay thousands ndash or even hundreds ndash to get your hands on something really special.If you know what yoursquore looking for you can find a spectacular dram on a supermarket shelf or in your local whisky shop, and you certainly wonrsquot need to spend as much as you think.Over the following four pages, Irsquove listed a few of my favourites ndash some of the most interesting and exciting whiskies around today. And nearly all of them cost less than pound.If you like what you read, go out and buy a bottle ndash I promise you that you wonrsquot be disappointed.Good luck!Ardnamurchan  ADABV : .%Price: poundLetrsquos start at the very beginning hellip with a dram so young wersquore not even allowed to call it whisky.Itrsquos generally accepted that the older whisky is, the better it gets, but Ardnamurchan  AD is definitely the exception that proves the rule. It boasts a depth of flavour that belies its youth ndash a heady mix of sweetness and citric sharpness, but with the richness of dried fruits and a satisfying biscuity creaminess. Far off there are hints of pepper and the odd waft of smoke. Yum!The  AD continues parent company Adelphirsquos pioneering use of blockchain to give unique levels of provenance to every bottle. By scanning the unique QR code on the back label, consumers can trace every ingredient and every stage of the ldquomanufacturing process, from field to bottle.And,yoursquore still not convinced, just look at the bottle. Simple and sleek, it won  Scottish Design Awards for packaging.So with just , bottles of this beauty ever made, itrsquos definitely worth a quick dash to grab one. It will probably be a collectorrsquos itemyou donrsquot open it. But having tasted it, that will be a really big ldquo!www.adelphidistilleryGlenkinchie -year-oldABV: %Price: poundIrsquoll never forget it.It was a pub in Dundee ndash I canrsquot remember the name but I do remember the location the Queenrsquos Hotel at the bottom of the Perth Road ndash and it was , I think.And I didnrsquot like whisky, until that amazing night when I tried Glenkinchie.My friend had bet me he could find me one that would change my mind. When he handed the Glenkinchie to me he said: ldquoLook for the ice cream.And when I drank it, it was there, coating my mouth and at the back of my tongue hellip and I was hooked!Nowadays, Irsquod say therersquos far more to this dram than hints of vanilla and a lemon cheesecake creaminess. In fact, I think that for a Lowland malt ndash itrsquos distilled just outside Edinburgh ndash it has a wonderful richness and depth, and it really stands scrutiny against the biggest guns of Speyside, and some of the great Highland malts.Add to that a lovely natural, almost herbal note and you have a dram that really is one to remember.www.maltsArran The Bothy Quarter Cask Batch ABV: .%Price: pound.They say the Isle of Arran is Scotland in Miniature. But, believe me, therersquos nothing miniatureabout this fantastic dram from a lovely distillery in the north of the island.It packs as impressive a punch as any expresssion Irsquove tried over the years.As you can guess from the name, this is the fourth release of the Quarter Cask. Each one so far has been an absolute winner, and this is no dferent.The idea is simple: take the usual Arran whisky and, for the last  months of its maturation, move it into smaller casks ndash yes, you guessed it, a quarter the size of the original and made of American Oak.This allows far greater contact between whisky and wood, resulting in a faster, more intense maturation.The result is an absolutetreat ndash rich and powerful with tonsof vanilla sweetness and peppery spice. Itrsquos fruity and fresh, but at the same time really luxurious.This is a real star in a brilliant range. The distillery is well worth a visit too ndash the scones are amazing!www.arranwhiskyKilchoman SanaigABV: %Price: poundSpeed bonnie boat like a bird on the wing, over the sea to Skye. We all know the song about Bonnie Prince Charlie but, seriously,yoursquore looking for a Young Pretender, yoursquod be far better jumping on the ferry to Islay.Kilchoman is the newest of the distilleries on this little patch of land thatrsquos jam-packed with wonderful whisky, but itrsquos already giving its globally recognised neighbours a run for their money.Following on from the Machir Bay, Kilchoman ups its game a little with the Sanaig.Itrsquos described as a peaty malt, but for me itrsquos got that beautul aroma of Arbroath Smokies ndash sharp wood-ember smokiness mixed with a wonderful creaminess thatrsquos simply irresistible.Add to that light fruit, dark chocolate and raisins, along with red-berry richness, and you could be on a picnic on a beach with your pals, chatting and laughing until the last of the embers of the fire die down.A real treat ndash and brilliant value.kilchomandistilleryBenromach -year-oldABV: %Price: pound.Sometimes whisky isnrsquot about posh tasting notes and fancy descriptions of complex aromas and flavours. Sometimes itrsquos about something thatrsquos far more simple.Sometimes, when you smell it, it transports you somewhere  ndash to a memory or a favourite place.For me, this -year-old Benromach does just that. It takes me back to when I was young, six or seven, maybe, to a time when we lived in an old house, with a big open fire, and we used to sit there of an evening ndash it would have been about this time of year ndash roasting marshmallows.I can smell the fire ndash not a roaring one, but mellow embers with the odd little puff of smoke. I can taste the rich toffee-sweetness of the melting marshmallows.But, therersquos something  too ndash is that Jamaica ginger cake  Not homemade, but the sticky one out of the packet. Itrsquos luxurious, and it makes me smile.So,you have a whisky and the tasting notes donrsquot make any sense to you, donrsquot worry. More powerful forces may be at work ndash just open your mind and see what you can see.www.benromachCaol Ila -year-oldABV: %Price: poundThis is another one ndash another malt that holds a special place in my heart.When my two daughters were young, this was the one I remember sitting back with as the madness of Christmas began to subside at the end of the day. And itrsquos still the one Irsquoll go forI see it on a menu after dinner at a hotel.Caol Ilais a Muhammad Ali of a dram hellip it dances around, all lightness and fruit itrsquos fascinating and mesmerising.But at some point or other, you just know itrsquos going to knock you out with a wonderful smack of smoke.It starts off light and refined, with fresh herbal notes and hints of damp grass, but then the coastal smokiness really kicks in ndash not unlike hot-smoked salmon. Itrsquos full-bodied and has a long, warming finish.As you add water, a wonderful freshness ndash much like Ardbeg ndash takes over, making this a hugely satisfying dram.www.maltsOld Particular Cameronbridge -year-oldABV: .%Price: poundWe couldnrsquot let a list of brilliant whiskies go without including a single-grain. And what better place to find one than at legendary Glasgow-based independent bottler Douglas Laing The Cameronbridge isnrsquot exactly blessed with the beautul surroundings of Strathisla or Glengoyne, or the rugged backdrop of Dalwhinnie ndash it sits in Fersquos industrial heartland, just a stonersquos throw from Methil and Leven.It may not have had the most romantic of beginnings, but this Cameronbridge is a real ndash and rare ndash treat.In my mind, the defining characteristic of single-grain whiskies is cream, and this expression is awash with it.In fact, when you smell it, therersquos almost an aroma oftoffee sauce ndash salted caramel mixed with all that cream, but with a bit of honey thrown in for good measure.You could almost pour it on your sponge pudding.Therersquos cakiness too ndash in fact, this is more like a big, rich sharing dessert than a dram.Now, wherersquos my spoon  I want another helping .www.douglaslaingcomOld Pulteney -year-oldABV: %Price: poundIf anyone ever says that whisky isnrsquot a product of its surroundings, this is definitely a dram to make them change their mind.Itrsquos made in Wick, and its warehouses are exposed to the full force of the North Sea.This gives the whisky a wonderful coastal, salty personality ndash and once you get to know it, you can recognise it anywhere.But donrsquot think this dram is harsh in any way at all. The -year-old is aged entirely in bourbon casks, and this gives the finished product a wonderful richness and sweetness ndash and the distinctive vanilla that is always there when bourbon casks are used.Look for vanilla, tablet and almost burnt sugar on the nose, with a flavour balancing chocolate and toffee indulgence with citrusy fruit and that coastal tang.This level of quality is great value at pound, but be aware that Old Pulteneyis regularly on offer ndash I think itrsquos pound in Tesco right now, and at that price itrsquos a steal.www.oldpulteneyKilkerran -year-oldABV: %Price: poundBefore we start, letrsquos take a moment to thank Kilkerran ndash because the distillery where itrsquos made, Glengyle, effectively saved Campbeltownrsquos status as a whisky region.After many years of only having two distilleries, Springbank and Glen Scotia, it was deemed that Campbeltown could no longer be classed as a region.However, when Glengyle was resurrected ndash it was an old distillery that closed in the s but was brought back to le in  ndash the three operational distilleries could maintain their status.And just as well, as Campbeltown malts are unique ndash robust, oily and bursting with character ndash and this Kilkerran -year-old is certainly a classic of its kind.Itrsquos oaky and slightly peaty, but super-rich, sweet and velvety smooth at the same time. And, of course, therersquos the oiliness and saltiness yoursquod expect from a Campbeltown dram.This whisky was only launched in , but it surely deserves its place among the true greats of this amazing region.All hail Kilkerran ndash you are indeed a hero!kilkerran.scotMacallan -year-old Double CaskABV: %Price: poundThe Macallan has been looking a million dollars lately hellip literally. One of its bottles ndash a -year-old distilled in  ndash broke that mad, seven-figure barrier just a few weeks ago, but far more importantlythe distillery moved house hellip to possibly the most beautully perfect building I have ever seen.So, as the year draws to a close, I was pretty sure my impression of this superbrand couldnrsquot get any more positive hellip until I tasted the Double Cask.Much of my whisky journey has been a hunt for the dferent and the new, but when I come back to a dram like The Macallan and its perfect richness, I remember therersquos a reason why this is a worldwide favourite.The Double Cask uses whisky aged in barrels of both American and European ex-sherry oak to take the spirit to a whole new level.Therersquos the classic dried fruit. Itrsquos creamy and you can almost see the drops of honey. But therersquos the sweet sharpness of marmalade and almost the spiced luxury of a cinnamon pastry.A finish of vanilla and more sweet fruit and I have only one challenge on my mind as we end .Go on Macallan, I dare you ndash top that next year.www.themacallanArdbeg An OaABV: .%Price: poundTo me, Ardbeg is about only one thing ndash itrsquos what identies it the minute I stick my nose in the glass.Smoke ndash pure, perfect, wood-embers smoke.And the An Oa ndash launched last year as the first addition to Ardbegrsquos core range for more than a decade ndash doesnrsquot disappoint.Itrsquos there in spades, mixed with a wonderful cocktail of cakey sweetness and butterscotch richness. Therersquos a luxurious creaminess in the background too, just in case you didnrsquot get just how special this dram really is.Then,you add water therersquos another treat in store ndash something I donrsquot understand from such a peaty whisky, but which I always look for in an Ardbeg.The peaty oomph remains, but something  appears ndash the most wonderful freshness. Itrsquos like a summer breeze blowing through freshly washed linen just hung out to dry on a line by the sea.If you like peaty whisky, you really canrsquot go wrong with Ardbeg, but this was the first time Irsquod tried the An Oa.Time to rewrite my whisky wish-list, I think!www.ardbegGordon  MacPhail Discovery Bunnahabhain -year-oldABV: %Price: poundThere are Islay whiskies ndash the ones that take a barrowload of peat and stuff it down your throat ndash and there are Islay whiskies ndash the ones that tone things down, some a teeny bit, some a lot. For me, Bunnahabhain sits in the second camp hellip and itrsquos all the better for it.So when Gordon  MacPhail ndash one of the countryrsquos small band of legendary independent bottlers ndash gets hold of an already interesting dram, itrsquos time to take notice.This Discovery expression ndash part of a wider range from around the country ndash is rich and exciting, with dried fruit and sherry on the nose, and hints of spice, rich vanilla and orange. Itrsquos super- smooth, and as you taste it the initial spice morphs into more richness of dates and plums. At the finish, therersquos chocolate ndash maybe not milky bar, but definitely not bitter dark ndash and more fruits.The bottlerrsquos art is a critical part of the whisky firmament ndash they hunt out interesting casks and, when they find them they bottle them. Soyou see a bottlerrsquos version of one of our favourites, go for it ndash you will definitely be in for a memorable voyage of Discovery.gordonandmacphailNaked GrouseABV: %Price: poundAs I said in the introduction to this whole article,yoursquore after something truly memorable, you really donrsquot have to spend a fortune to get it hellipyou know where to look. And at under pound in some shops, the Naked Grouse is in my mind a must-have for any collection.Pour it for your whisky-loving friend ndash but donrsquot show them the bottle ndash and watch as they muse over the malty, toffee-sweet nose and rich fudgy, fruity flavour, topped off with a little spice, and tryto identy what high-end dram it belongs to.Soyoursquore looking for a superb, great-value dram, just remember one thing ndash sometimes less really is more.nakedgrouseTomatin -year-oldABV: %Price: poundAs you head up the A, by the time to reach Tomatin you know yoursquore in the Highlands. The bleak splendour of Drumochter and Dalwhinnie are miles behind the Cairngorms and Aviemore are a rapidly fading memory. Inverness isnrsquot far off, and from there itrsquos on to the wild lands of Ross and Caithness.Yoursquod expect a whisky here to have ruggedness its heart ndash to be as unforgiving as a northern winter. But no, not a bit of it. The climate round here is softer and more gentle than you might imagine ndash and the spirit thatrsquos born from this land reflects that.The Tomatin -year-old is smooth and silky, with a rich, fruity aroma coming from its traditional mix of ex-bourbon and ex-sherry casks. Itrsquos buttery at first, but there are also notes of marzipan. The flavours are powerful, but therersquos sweetness and richness, with oaky vanilla, ripe apples and pears. Hints of stem ginger and citrus add a tangy treat.Soyou ever thought the Highlands were bleak, think again. All you need to do is stop a while, look around you, and yoursquoll find a real gem hidden in the north.www.tomatinDouglas Laingrsquos Remarkable Regional MaltsABV: VariousPrice: From pound to poundI could choose one from this range, but really, therersquos no point. Quite simply,you try one you really should try them all, because theyrsquore as good a lesson in the dferent characteristics of Scotlandrsquos whisky regions as yoursquoll ever need. Theyrsquore a ready-made whisky collection.There are six names to look out for, and each blends together some of the best malts from its region to capture the unique character of each area.The fun, light Epicurean is the lowland offering, while rich,complex Speyside is represented by Scallywag.If you head into the Highlands, look out for Timorous Beastie, and slightly peated, slightly salty Rock Oyster is a island-inspired tidal wave.If yoursquore into a dram from Islay or Skye, why not try Big Beat , while the newest addition to the range,The Gauldrons, captures the unique, excellent power of Campbeltown.The range was launched with ldquobasic versions, but since then it has grown, and a host of special editions and extra expressions have turned these Regional Malts into a veritable reference library of whisky.So put on your reading glasses, pull up a chair and get studying. You will be tested at the end of the lesson.www.douglaslaingOld Pulteney HuddartABV: %Price: poundThis is a strange experience. Old Pulteney has been a favourite of mine for many, many years, but trying the Huddart ndash released just this year and named after the street in which the distillery sits ndash was like meeting the younger sister of my best pal that I didnrsquot know existed.I recognise her immediately, but at the same time shersquos so dferent from the friend I know and love.The Huddart is definitely an Old Pulteney ndash the saltiness and drtwood-on-a-beach coastal personality tell us that ndash but itrsquos been finished in casks which previously held peated whisky, and this gives it a wonderful far-off smokiness that adds a layer of real intensity to an already powerful dram.But therersquos a ton of richness too, with sweet vanilla balancing the intensity of smoke, and I loved the buttery, mouth-coating finish. This is definitely one to come back to on a cold, stormy night when I have some time on my hands, and the music player to myself. Van Morrison, I think.Huddart, itrsquos been a pleasure to make your acquaintance. I hope we run into each other again soon.www.oldpulteney.coTullibardine SovereignABV: %Price: poundAnd your starter for  ndash where do you think you would find the complete dram  The lush valleys of Speyside, perhaps  Or the rugged coast of Islay But whatI said just off theA on the way from Stirling to Perth Chances are yoursquoll have passed the Tullibardine distillery at one time or another. But did you know itrsquos one of the few in the country where every whisky-making process is done on-site Fermentation, distillation, maturation, and bottling ndash itrsquos all done here.This gives Tullibardine complete control over its whisky, and allows it to produce expressions like the Sovereign ndash a creamy, rich, delicious dram.On the nose, look for soft vanilla and cocoa butter, and when you taste it the richness builds with malt and hints of maple syrup, with a little extra helping of mixed peel and pears. The finish is all cream and vanilla with a touch of cinnamon-spice.For the whisky from the side of the A, itrsquos a definite A+ from me!www.tullibardine

title: pm-and-party-leaders-pay-tribute-to-paddy-ashdown
story: Sir Vince Cable and past Lib Dem leaders joined Theresa May, Jeremy Corbyn and others including Tony Blair in hailing the dedication and decency of the politician and former commando, who passed away on Saturday evening.The former party leader, who was credited with making the Lib Dems a signicant third force in politics during his tenure between  and , had announced he was suffering from bladder cancer in November.The party announced his passing, saying he would be remembered ldquoas someone who made an immeasurable contribution to furthering the cause of liberalism.Sir Vince Cable, the partyrsquos current leader, said it was ldquoa hugely sad day for the party and everyone  across politics ldquowho had immense affection and respect for Paddy.He hailed a man who ldquowas famous for his politics, but his talents extended well beyond that arena.Born in India and raised in Northern Ireland, he later served in the Royal Marines and Special Boat Service, including in Borneo and the Persian Gulf.He hit the headlines four years into his leadership of the Lib Dems when, in , he revealed he had had a five-month affair with his secretary, which led The Sun to nickname him ldquoPaddy Pantsdown.His marriage to we Jane survived the scandal.After stepping down as leader, Ashdown, who was MP for Yeovil from  to , was first knighted and then made a peer as Lord Ashdown of Norton-sub-Hamdon when he quit the Commons.He became High Representative for Bosnia and Herzegovina in May  and, more recently, went on to play a role in the Remain campaign during the  referendum, appearing alongside then-PM David Cameron and Lord Kinnock, the former Labour leader.After revealing his cancer diagnosis, he tweeted that it ldquodoes not merit a fuss, adding: ldquoMany go through this. The NHS guys in Yeovil Hosp. are BRILLIANT.ldquoI have the best of people and the best of friends to fight this with, which makes me, as so often in my le, very lucky.Sir Nick Clegg, who would as leader take the Liberal Democrats into government in , said Lord Ashdown had been ldquothe reason I entered politics and became ldquoa lelong mentor, friend and guide.He added: ldquoHe was a soldier, a diplomat, a writer, a leader, a campaigner, a servant of his constituents, and an international statesman.ldquoBut the thing I admired most in him is that rarest of gts ndash a politician without an ounce of cynicism.Tributes also came in from his former political opponents, with Sir John Major saying he was ldquoa man of duty, passion, and devotion to the country he loved ndash right up to the very end.Former Labour prime minister Tony Blair said he admired the former Lib Dem leader ldquoas a man and as a political visionary and leader, saying he had been ldquoexcellent company, always fun to be around.And Mr Blairrsquos successor Gordon Brown described Lord Ashdown as ldquoone of the towering political figures of our generation who spoke always as a strong European, a committed internationalist and a dedicated constitutional reformer.Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, hailed Lord Ashdownrsquos work in Bosnia, saying: ldquoPaddy Ashdown was an advocate for those others forgot, full of courage, integrity and immensely gted.ldquoHe served the people of the Balkans with passion and inspiration, an agent of reconciliation.Current Prime Minister Theresa May said Lord Ashdown had ldquoserved his country with distinction, adding: ldquoHe dedicated his le to public service and he will be sorely missed.Former Tory international development secretary Andrew Mitchell, who worked with him during the coalition years, said Lord Ashdown had been ldquoa wonderful man and a hugely effective politician who had been admired by Margaret Thatcher.Mr Mitchell told the Press Association: ldquoHe was an extraordinary character. Mrs Thatcher had immense respect for him and although he was a political opponent, held his views in the highest regard.

title: the-open-drives-120m-boost-for-scottish-economy
story: The th Open attracted a record , fans in July to watch the tournament won by Francesco Molinari, who became the first Italian to lt the Claret Jug.The Open has been played in Scotland more often than any other country, with Carnoustie hosting the event for the first time since , surpassing the , attendance record set in .An independent study found the economic impact of the tournament was a boost of pound million, in addition to pound million in destination marketing activity from The Open being broadcast on television to more than  million households in  countries.Welcoming the research by Sheffield Hallam Universityrsquos Sport Industry Research Centre, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said: ldquoThe Open Championship is synonymous with Scotland as the home of golf, and this yearrsquos Open at Carnoustie once again showcased Scotland internationally as the perfect stage for major events.ldquoThe figures released today also demonstrate the economic benefits of hosting major events and Irsquom pleased the th Open generated signicant income for both the local Angus area and for the wider Scottish economy.ldquoWe look forward to bringing The Open back to Scotland in  when it s to St Andrews, and of course we will welcome the world to Gleneagles next September for the Solheim Cup.The study ndash which was commissioned by golfrsquos governing body the RA, VisitScotland and Angus Council ndash also concluded the Angus area alone received a pound million injection of new money from The Open.Almost half of the spectators who attendedtravelled from outside Scotland, while the majority of Scottish fanscame from outside Angus.Sixty-two per cent of non-Angus residents indicated they wouldto the region for a break within  months.David Fairweather, leader of Angus Council, said: ldquoWe were delighted to welcome The Open back, along with a record , fans. We all enjoyed a fantastic event that attracted global interest and attention, as well as immediate and long-lasting economic benefits to local and regional communities and business.ldquopound million of new money into the local economy is great news for Angus, its people, hotels, BBs, shops and restaurants.ldquoThe th Open at Carnoustie was outstanding and my message to those who joined us and to The RA is straightforward ndash Haste Ye Back.Martin Slumbers, RA chief executive, added: ldquoThe Open has a proven track record of generating substantial economic benefit for the host country in which it is staged thanks to the tens of thousands of spectators who attend each year.ldquoTheof The Open to Carnoustie has been a great success. We enjoyed a memorable week in which we welcomed a record number of fans to one of golfrsquos great championship venues to witness Francesco Molinari create history by becoming the first Italian to lt the iconic Claret Jug.

title: tory-party-sparks-social-media-storm-after-posting-poll-about-festive-food-as-thousands-face-christmas-on-the-breadline
story: The poll, published from the official Conservative Party Twitter account on Friday, said: "Right, time now for an all-important Christmas poll: which is better " Giving followers the options of choosing either mince pies or pigs in blankets as answers.Over , Twitter users have responded to the poll with the majority highlighting the Conservative Governments failings to address the rising poverty crisis affecting the UK.Many Twitter users responded to the poll calling it "distasteful" and "disgraceful" with many commenting on how "out of touch" the Tory Party is with society.In response to the poll, James Lazarus posted: "Distasteful considering the mess UK is in right now because of your party. Millions will have a rotten Christmas because of the Tory austerity policy and the rubbish Tory Brexit you want to inflict on the country."Julie Peel created her own pollin response with the choices of eating or heating.Ben Williams posted: "The #irony of this Tweet when @Conservatives policies have reduced families to starvation. Food bank use has gone through the roof since . Shameful."Dale Ricketts posted: "Scrolled as far down as I can in this thread without smashing my head against a brick wall... not a single positive response was seen. How are you Tories still so out of touch with reality "Mark Willett also responded to the poll commenting onthe Tories detachment from public opinion: "A tweet from people who really donrsquot have ANY idea how far detached they are from public opinion and Irsquod say the sameany other party tweeted this insignicant nonsense."But in amongst the negative comments and robust replies, a few Twitter users showed support for the Conservative Government.Nora Rose responded to the negativity by tweeting: "Dont just blame the Conservatives blame the whole of Parliament.
